      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13b
      Multifunctionality and Crystal Dynamics of a Highly Stable, Porous Metal-Organic Framework [Zn4O(NTB)2]
      Lee, Eun Young; Jang, Seung Yeon; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (17), 6374-6381CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A porous metal-org. framework [Zn4O(NTB)2]·3DEF·EtOH (1), in which (3,6)-connected nets are doubly interpenetrated to generate curved three-dimensional channels, was prepd. Framework 1 exhibits high permanent porosity (Langmuir surface area, 1121 m2/g; pore vol., 0.51 cm3/cm3), high thermal stability (up to 430°), high H adsorption capacity (1.9% at 77 K and 1 atm), selective org. guest binding ability (Kf: MeOH > pyridine > benzene > dodecane), and guest-dependent blue luminescence (λmax depending on guest identity). Most interestingly, the framework sustains single crystallinity even at 400° and 10-5 Torr, and the framework components undergo reversible dynamics, mainly rotational motion, in response to removal and rebinding of the guest mols.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13c
      Two 3D Porous Lanthanide-Fumarate-Oxalate Frameworks Exhibiting Framework Dynamics and Luminescent Change upon Reversible De- and Rehydration
      Zhu, Wen-Hua; Wang, Zhe-Ming; Gao, Song
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (4), 1337-1342CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors present two porous luminescent compds., [Ln2(fumarate)2(oxalate)(H2O)4]·4H2O (Ln = Eu, Tb), prepd. by the hydrothermal method. The materials have 3-dimensional framework structure consisting of oxalate pillared lanthanide-fumarate layers with intersected channels occupied by guest H2O. They exhibit framework dynamics upon several cycles of dehydration and rehydration. The crystallinity of the as-prepd. hydrated materials degrades completely to the amorphous dehydrated phases, while it returns upon rehydration. A mechanism for de-/rehydration is proposed from the structure and spectroscopic data. The dehydration process is accompanied by the lost of luminescence of Ln ion, but the luminescence is recovered upon rehydration, where H2O mols. in fact enhance the luminescence but not quench it. This is probably due to the softened environment of lanthanide ion in the dehydrated amorphous phases and the recovery of the stiffness after rehydration.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltlamtg%253D%253D&md5=f640834977487441ec89f1c12817856d

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Three-Dimensional Lanthanide Anionic Metal-Organic Frameworks with Tunable Luminescent Properties Induced by Cation Exchange
      Lu, Wen-Guan; Jiang, Long; Feng, Xiao-Long; Lu, Tong-Bu
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (15), 6997-6999CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three 3-dimensional lanthanide anionic metal-org. frameworks, {K5[Ln5(IDC)4(ox)4]·20H2O}n, with 1-dimensional channels were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions [IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate, ox = oxalate, Ln = Gd (1), Tb (2), and Dy (3)]. The K+ ions within the 1-dimensional channel are easily exchanged with various cations. The emission intensities of TbIII in 2 increased significantly upon the addn. of Ca2+ ions, while the introduction of other metal ions caused the intensities to be either unchanged or weakened.

      A Miniaturized Linear pH Sensor Based on a Highly Photoluminescent Self-Assembled Europium(III) Metal-Organic Framework

      A miniaturized prototype for pH sensing in the pH range 5-7.5 has been constructed from a photoluminescent Eu3+ metal-org. framework that contains two different Eu3+ sites and self-assembles through hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions. This material has a very high quantum yield and an excellent balance between absorption, energy transfer, and emission rate.

      13f
      Porous Phosphorescent Coordination Polymers for Oxygen Sensing
      Xie, Zhigang; Ma, Liqing; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Jin, Athena; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (3), 922-923CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium tris(2-phenylpyridine) derivs. were designed and incorporated into coordination polymers as tricarboxylate bridging ligands. Three different cryst. coordination polymers were synthesized using a solvothermal technique and were characterized using a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, IR spectroscopy, gas adsorption measurements, and luminescence measurements. The coordination polymer built from Ir[3-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 1, is highly porous with a nitrogen BET surface area of 764 m2/g, whereas the coordination polymers built from Ir[4-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 2 and 3, were nonporous. The 3MLCT phosphorescence of each of the three coordination polymers was quenched in the presence of O2. However, only 1 showed quick and reversible luminescence quenching by oxygen, whereas 2 and 3 exhibited gradual and irreversible luminescence quenching by oxygen. The high permanent porosity of 1 allows for rapid diffusion of oxygen through the open channels, leading to efficient and reversible quenching of the 3MLCT phosphorescence. This work highlights the opportunity of designing highly porous and luminescent coordination polymers for sensing other important analytes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1alurrL&md5=5b4db906f93aa4289f08b1946f61662e

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      A robust near infrared luminescent ytterbium metal-organic framework for sensing of small molecules
      Guo, Zhiyong; Xu, Hui; Su, Shengqun; Cai, Jianfeng; Dang, Song; Xiang, Shengchang; Qian, Guodong; Zhang, Hongjie; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin

      The 1st near-IR luminescent ytterbium metal-org. framework, Yb(BPT)(H2O).(DMF)1.5(H2O)1.25 (BPT = biphenyl 3,4',5-tricarboxylate), was realized for the highly selective and sensitive sensing of small mols.

      (h) Ferrando-Soria, J.; Khajavi, H.; Serra-Crespo, P.; Gascon, J.; Kapteijn, F.; Julve, M.; Lloret, F.; Pasán, J.; Ruiz-Pérez, C.; Journaux, Y.; Pardo, E. Highly selective chemical sensing in a luminescent nanoporous magnet Adv. Mater. 2012, 24, 5625– 5629 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201201846

      13h
      Highly Selective Chemical Sensing in a Luminescent Nanoporous Magnet
      Ferrando-Soria, Jesus; Khajavi, Hossein; Serra-Crespo, Pablo; Gascon, Jorge; Kapteijn, Freek; Julve, Miguel; Lloret, Francesc; Pasan, Jorge; Ruiz-Perez, Catalina; Journaux, Yves; Pardo, Emilio
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2012), 24 (41), 5625-5629CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Presented are the synthesis, crystal structure, thermal and sorption behavior, optical and magnetic properties of a new manganese(II)-copper(II) 2D metal-org. framework (MOF) of formula MV[Mn2Cu3(mpba)3(H2O)3]•20H2O (1), where MV2+ is the methylviologen dicationic dye and mpba4- is the N,N'-1,3-phenylenebis(oxamate) bridging ligand. Compd. 1 exhibits highly selective gas sorption ability, luminescence capacity, and long-range magnetic ordering, constituting thus a unique example of luminescent porous magnet with potential applications in host-guest chem. sensing of small mols. The accessible porosity of the anhyd. deriv. of 1 was calcd. by means of gas adsorption isotherms at room temp. CO2 is able to enter the pores with a satn. loading of 1.5 mol kg-1 at 30 bar. Other gas mols. like CH4 or bigger hydrocarbons were not adsorbed. Challenged by the selective gas sorption results obtained by using CO2 and CH4 as analytes similar emission measurements were performed through a coating of the anhyd. deriv. of 1 under different single gases and gas mixt. atmospheres. The emission spectrum after CH4 treatment still corresponds with the one of the dehydrated framework, demonstrating that CH4 does not adsorb. In contrast, a considerable red-shift is obsd. when CO2 is adsorbed. For a CO2-CH4 mixt., the results are similar to those obtained with pure CO2. Since CH4 does not adsorb on the framework, the luminescence response to CO2 is similar as for the single gas expt., demonstrating that CO2 can be detected in the presence of non-adsorbing gases, i.e. methane.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFOmt7bE&md5=09b11d2a42cbc2a85bf2b7053f86be4e

      (a) Wang, J. H.; Li, M.; Li, D. A dynamic, luminescent and entangled MOF as a qualitative sensor for volatile organic solvents and a quantitative monitor for acetonitrile vapour Chem. Sci. 2013, 4, 1793– 1801 DOI: 10.1039/c3sc00016h
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14a
      A dynamic, luminescent and entangled MOF as a qualitative sensor for volatile organic solvents and a quantitative monitor for acetonitrile vapour
      Wang, Jun-Hao; Li, Mian; Li, Dan
      Chemical Science (2013), 4 (4), 1793-1801CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A new luminescent entangled (srs nets with 2-fold interpenetration, linked via short Cu···Cu distances of ∼2.8 Å) MOF, namely, [(CuCN)3L·(guest)x]n (L =2,6-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)pyridine; x =1 or 2), which contains microporous channels, is synthesized. This MOF material shows structural dynamics upon adsorption of various volatile org. solvent mols., accompanied by reversible guest responsive color changes of the fluorescence emission that are discernible by the naked eyes. The vacuated form of this material can also exhibit qual. solvate-optical sensing behaviors toward various mixed solvents. A quant. real-time monitoring device is constructed that implements the detn. of acetonitrile vapor pressure through optical response, which causes a drastic emission change from blue to yellow. The detailed structural elucidation provides structure-property understanding for the host-guest responsive dynamics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjtlymsbo%253D&md5=d88aae265addfc3292c17101b21fc58d
      (b) Song, X. Z.; Song, S. Y.; Zhao, S. N.; Hao, Z. M.; Zhu, M.; Meng, X.; Wu, L. L.; Zhang, H. J. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation of a europium(III) metal-organic framework producing a multi-responsive luminescent sensor Adv. Funct. Mater. 2014, 24, 4034– 4041 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201303986
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14b
      Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Transformation of a Europium(III) Metal-Organic Framework Producing a Multi-responsive Luminescent Sensor
      Song, Xue-Zhi; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhao, Shu-Na; Hao, Zhao-Min; Zhu, Min; Meng, Xing; Wu, Lan-Lan; Zhang, Hong-Jie
      Advanced Functional Materials (2014), 24 (26), 4034-4041CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A sensor with a red-emission signal is successfully obtained by the solvothermal reaction of Eu3+ and heterofunctional ligand bpydbH2 (4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid), followed by terminal-ligand exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. As a result of treatments both before and after the metal-org. framework formation, accessible Lewis-base sites and coordinated water mols. are successfully anchored onto the host material, and they act as signal transmission media for the recognition of analytes at the mol. level. This is the 1st reported sensor based on a metal-org. framework (MOF) with multi-responsive optical sensing properties. It is capable of sensing small org. mols. and inorg. ions, and unprecedentedly it can discriminate among the homologs and isomers of aliph. alcs. as well as detect highly explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in water or in the vapor phase. This work highlights the practical application of luminescent MOFs as sensors, and it paves the way toward other multi-responsive sensors by demonstrating the incorporation of various functional groups into a single framework.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXks1Wqt70%253D&md5=1590a1dc92771564306f581f4155e753
      (c) Nickerl, G.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S. Tetrazine functionalized zirconium MOF as an optical sensor for oxidizing gases Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 2280– 2282 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC08136F

      14c
      Tetrazine functionalized zirconium MOF as an optical sensor for oxidizing gases
      Nickerl, Georg; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (12), 2280-2282CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Dihydro-1,2,4,5-tetrazine-3,6-dicarboxylate was introduced into the chem. stable UiO-66 structure by a postsynthetic linker exchange reaction to create an optical sensor material for the detection of oxidative agents such as nitrous gases. The incorporated tetrazine unit can be reversibly oxidized and reduced, which is accompanied by a drastic color change from yellow to pink and vice versa. The high stability of the framework during redox reaction was proven by powder x-ray diffraction and nitrogen physisorption measurements.

      Metal-organic frameworks for luminescence thermometry
      Cui, Yuanjing; Zhu, Fengliang; Chen, Banglin; Qian, Guodong
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (35), 7420-7431CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) hold great promise for developing various types of luminescent sensors due to their remarkable structural diversity and tunable luminescence properties. In the last few years, using luminescent MOFs to explore temp. sensing has gained intense attention. In this feature article, after the general description of luminescence thermometry, the authors have summarized the recent progress made in luminescent MOF thermometers, with particular emphasis on the dual-emitting MOFs that effectively illustrate the self-referencing temp. measurement based on the intensity ratios of 2 sep. transitions.

      14e
      Encapsulating Pyrene in a Metal-Organic Zeolite for Optical Sensing of Molecular Oxygen
      Ye, Jia-Wen; Zhou, Hao-Long; Liu, Si-Yang; Cheng, Xiao-Ning; Lin, Rui-Biao; Qi, Xiao-Lin; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Chemistry of Materials (2015), 27 (24), 8255-8260CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Pyrene is a good oxygen-sensitive probe with high fluorescence quantum yield, suitable sensitivity, and high photostability when dispersed in gas-permeable org. polymers, but it is a carcinogen and environmental pollutant and tends to aggregate and/or evap. at high temp./low pressure. In this work, we show that pyrene can be easily and firmly encapsulated in a metal-org. zeolite SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (Hmim = 2-methylimidazole, MAF-4 or ZIF-8) via an in situ loading strategy, giving fluorescence O2-sensing materials not only with fast response, high photostability, and tunable sensitivity but also free of pyrene aggregation/leak and interference by other quenchers. Moreover, these host-guest inclusion crystals can be easily fabricated as thin film sensors and aerodynamic coatings.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFSmtbzI&md5=d089626766af1df4735f61ced278cc8c
      (f) Zhao, J.; Wang, Y. N.; Dong, W. W.; Wu, Y. P.; Li, D. S.; Zhang, Q. C. A robust luminescent Tb(III)-MOF with lewis basic pyridyl sites for the highly sensitive detection of metal ions and small molecules Inorg. Chem. 2016, 55, 3265– 3271 DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b02294

      A Robust Luminescent Tb(III)-MOF with Lewis Basic Pyridyl Sites for the Highly Sensitive Detection of Metal Ions and Small Molecules
      Zhao, Jun; Wang, Ye-Nan; Dong, Wen-Wen; Wu, Ya-Pan; Li, Dong-Sheng; Zhang, Qi-Chun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2016), 55 (7), 3265-3271CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A new luminescent terbium-metal-org. framework [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O (1) (H4L = 4,4'-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)diisophthalic acid) was successfully assembled by Tb3+ ions and an undeveloped pyridyl-tetracarboxylate. Compd. 1 exhibits a 3-dimensional porous (3,8)-connected (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topol. framework with fascinating 1-dimensional open hydrophilic channels decorated by uncoordinated Lewis basic pyridyl N atoms. In particular, the Tb-MOF (1) can detect Cu2+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity, and its luminescence is nearly entirely quenched in DMF soln. and biol. system. 1 Still has high detection for the trace content of nitromethane with 70 ppm, which suggests that 1 is a promising example of a dual functional material with sensing Cu ions and nitromethane.

      Spectroscopic and Crystallographic Investigations of Novel BODIPY-Derived Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Li, Ming; Yao, Yi; Ding, Jie; Liu, Lu; Qin, Jianhua; Zhao, Yaopeng; Hou, Hongwei; Fan, Yaoting
      Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (4), 1346-1353CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      To explore new 4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (BODIPY)-derived metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), the authors employed 2,6-dicarboxyl-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-phenyl-4,4-difluoroboradiazaindacene (H2L) as a ligand to successfully synthesize five coordination polymers, namely, {[Zn2(L)2(bpp)]·2H2O·2EtOH}n (1), {[Cd2(L)2(bpp)]·2H2O·EtOH}n (2), {[Cd2(L)(bpe)3(NO3)2]·2H2O·DMF·EtOH}n (3), {[Cd(L)(bpe)0.5(DMF)(H2O)]}n (4), and {[Cd(L)(bpe)0.5]·1.5H2O·DMF}n (5) (bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane, bpe = 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane). Except for two 2D-layer coordination polymers 3 and 4, the rest samples exhibit 3D metal-org. frameworks with certain pore sizes, esp. MOFs 1 and 5. Spectroscopic and crystallog. investigations demonstrate that the absorption and emission energies of the BODIPY chromophores are sensitive to the coordination modes. Moreover, in case 2, the transition metal centers coordinated with the dicarboxylate ligands L2- are capable of forming the two BODIPY units in coplanar arrangements (θ = 37.9°), simultaneously suppressing the uncommon J-dimer absorption band centered at 705 nm with a long tail into the near-IR region at room temp. However, in comparison with the ligand H2L, the emission of monomer-like BODIPY in case 3 is enhanced in the solid state by a considerably long distance between the parallel BODIPY planes (∼14.0 Å).

      (a) Chen, J. W.; Cao, Y. Development of novel conjugated donor polymers for high-efficiency bulk-heterojunction photovoltaic devices Acc. Chem. Res. 2009, 42, 1709– 1718 DOI: 10.1021/ar900061z
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16a
      Development of Novel Conjugated Donor Polymers for High-Efficiency Bulk-Heterojunction Photovoltaic Devices
      Chen, Junwu; Cao, Yong
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2009), 42 (11), 1709-1718CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Org. photovoltaic technol. is emerging as a potential competitor to silicon-based photovoltaic cells, and their power conversion efficiencies can now exceed 6%. Polymeric bulk-heterojunction photovoltaic cells, whose photoactive layer is composed of a blend of bicontinuous and interpenetrating donors and acceptors, can maximize interfacial area between the donor and the acceptor. Classic polymer donors, such as dialkoxy-substituted poly(p-phenylene vinylene)s and poly(3-hexylthiophene), have been widely investigated. However, advances in synthetic methodol. provide new avenues for the development of novel conjugated polymer donors with improved power conversion efficiencies. This paper primarily focuses on novel donor polymers that have shown power conversion efficiencies >1%. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole, thiophene, thieno[3,4-b]pyrazine, quinoxaline, and silole have emerged as useful heterocycles for constructing a variety of conjugated polymers for photovoltaic applications. We summarize useful information, such as mol. wts., absorption, bandgap, energy levels, and their photovoltaic performances with detailed device parameters, about these novel donor polymers. We use statistical summaries to evaluate several important parameter relationships among these polymer donors including open-circuit voltage vs. HOMO, power conversion efficiency vs. bandgap, and power conversion efficiency vs. hole mobility. Further statistical anal. of the data may guide further structural design and evaluation of polymer donor materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotVGktrs%253D&md5=608eed761b19d5f4630af5844480b630
      (b) Beaujuge, P. M.; Amb, C. M.; Reynolds, J. R. Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions Acc. Chem. Res. 2010, 43, 1396– 1407 DOI: 10.1021/ar100043u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16b
      Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions
      Beaujuge, Pierre M.; Amb, Chad M.; Reynolds, John R.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2010), 43 (11), 1396-1407CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. With the development of light-harvesting org. materials for solar cell applications and mol. systems with fine-tuned colors for nonemissive electrochromic devices (e.g., smart windows, e-papers), a no. of tech. challenges remain to be overcome. Over the years, the concept of "spectral engineering" (tailoring the complex interplay between mol. physics and the various optical phenomena occurring across the electromagnetic spectrum) has become increasingly relevant in the field of π-conjugated org. polymers. Within the spectral engineering toolbox, the "donor-acceptor" approach uses alternating electron-rich and electron-deficient moieties along a π-conjugated backbone. This approach has proved esp. valuable in the synthesis of dual-band and broadly absorbing chromophores with useful photovoltaic and electrochromic properties. In this Account, we highlight and provide insight into a present controversy surrounding the origin of the dual band of absorption sometimes encountered in semiconducting polymers structured using the "donor-acceptor" approach. Based on empirical evidence, we provide some schematic representations to describe the possible mechanisms governing the evolution of the two-band spectral absorption obsd. on varying the relative compn. of electron-rich and electron-deficient substituents along the π-conjugated backbone. In parallel, we draw attention to the choice of the method employed to est. and compare the absorption coeffs. of polymer chromophores exhibiting distinct repeat unit lengths, and contg. various extents of solubilizing side-chains along their backbone. Finally, we discuss the common assumption that "donor-acceptor" systems should have systematically lower absorption coeffs. than their "all-donor" counterparts. The proposed models point toward important theor. parameters which could be further explored at the macromol. level to help researchers take full advantage of the complex interactions taking place in π-conjugated polymers with intramol. "donor-acceptor" characteristics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVGrsLvK&md5=0bbbe078124296890ffce78d02e85c3d
      (c) Li, Y. F. Molecular design of photovoltaic materials for polymer solar cells: toward suitable electronic energy levels and broad absorption Acc. Chem. Res. 2012, 45, 723– 733 DOI: 10.1021/ar2002446
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16c
      Molecular Design of Photovoltaic Materials for Polymer Solar Cells: Electronic Energy Levels and Broad Absorption
      Li, Yongfang
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2012), 45 (5), 723-733CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Bulk heterojunction (BHJ) polymer solar cells (PSCs) sandwich a blend layer of conjugated polymer donor and fullerene deriv. acceptor between a transparent ITO pos. electrode and a low work function metal neg. electrode. In comparison with traditional inorg. semiconductor solar cells, PSCs offer a simpler device structure, easier fabrication, lower cost, and lighter wt., and these structures can be fabricated into flexible devices. But currently the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the PSCs is not sufficient for future commercialization. The polymer donors and fullerene deriv. acceptors are the key photovoltaic materials that will need to be optimized for high-performance PSCs. The basic requirements and scientific issues are discussed in the mol. design of high efficiency photovoltaic mols. Recent progress is also summarized in electronic energy level engineering and absorption spectral broadening of the donor and acceptor photovoltaic materials by my research group and others. For high-efficiency conjugated polymer donors, key requirements are a narrower energy bandgap (Eg) and broad absorption, relatively lower-lying HOMO level, and higher hole mobility. There are three strategies to meet these requirements: D-A copolymn. for narrower Eg and lower-lying HOMO, substitution with electron-withdrawing groups for lower-lying HOMO, and two-dimensional conjugation for broad absorption and higher hole mobility. Moreover, better main chain planarity and less side chain steric hindrance could strengthen π-π stacking and increase hole mobility. Furthermore, the mol. wt. of the polymers also influences their photovoltaic performance. To produce high efficiency photovoltaic polymers, researchers should attempt to increase mol. wt. while maintaining soly. High-efficiency D-A copolymers were obtained by using benzodithiophene (BDT), dithienosilole (DTS), or indacenodithiophene (IDT) donor unit and benzothiadiazole (BT), thienopyrrole-dione (TPD), or thiazolothiazole (TTz) acceptor units. The BDT unit with two thienyl conjugated side chains is a highly promising unit in constructing high-efficiency copolymer donor materials. The electron-withdrawing groups of ester, ketone, fluorine, or sulfonyl can effectively tune the HOMO energy levels downward. To improve the performance of fullerene deriv. acceptors, researchers will need to strengthen absorption in the visible spectrum, upshift the LUMO energy level, and increase the electron mobility. [6,6]-Phenyl-C71-butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) is superior to [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) because C70 absorbs visible light more efficiently. Indene-C60 bisadduct (ICBA) and Indene-C70 bisadduct (IC70BA) show 0.17 and 0.19 eV higher LUMO energy levels, resp., than PCBM, due to the electron-rich character of indene and the effect of bisadduct. ICBA and IC70BA are excellent acceptors for the P3HT-based PSCs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsVyrtr0%253D&md5=0c17f7095d4bc40d80db35233f0dc35f
      (d) Neto, B. A. D.; Lapis, A. A. M.; da Silva Júnior, E. N.; Dupont, J. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole and derivatives: synthesis, properties, reactions, and applications in light technology of small molecules Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2013, 2013, 228– 255 DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201201161
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole and Derivatives: Synthesis, Properties, Reactions, and Applications in Light Technology of Small Molecules
      Neto, Brenno A. D.; Lapis, Alexandre A. M.; da Silva, Eufranio N., Jr.; Dupont, Jairton
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 2013 (2), 228-255CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole (BTD) is one of the most important nuclei used in the chem. of photoluminescent compds. and applicable for light technol. The understanding of its properties and reactions is fundamental for the design and application of these derivs. in mol. org. electronic devices and for other technologies. As a result of their potential as constituents of org. light-emitting diodes, solar cells, liq. crystals, dyes, photovoltaic cells, and many others, attention has been focused on BTD π-extended derivs. with potential use in this exciting area. Herein, we describe their syntheses, properties, reactions, and selected examples of applications in light technol. using by BTD (small mols.) as the core.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVSisb3E&md5=0cacae09ae86eff8844d5958eea3726a
      (e) Parker, T. C.; Pa-tel, D. G.; Moudgil, K.; Barlow, S.; Risko, C.; Brédas, J. L.; Reynolds, J. R.; Marder, S. R. Heteroannulated acceptors based on benzothiadiazole Mater. Horiz. 2015, 2, 22– 36 DOI: 10.1039/C4MH00102H
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16e
      Heteroannulated acceptors based on benzothiadiazole
      Parker, Timothy C.; Patel, Dinesh G.; Moudgil, Karttikay; Barlow, Stephen; Risko, Chad; Bredas, Jean-Luc; Reynolds, John R.; Marder, Seth R.
      Materials Horizons (2015), 2 (1), 22-36CODEN: MHAOBM; ISSN:2051-6355. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Increasing the acceptor strength of the widely used acceptor benzothiadiazole (BT) by extending the heterocyclic core is a promising strategy for developing new and stronger acceptors for materials in org. electronics and photonics. In recent years, such heteroannulated BT acceptors have been incorporated into a wide variety of materials that have been used in org. electronic and photonic devices. This review critically assesses the properties of these materials. Although heteroannulation to form acceptors, such as benzo[1,2-c:4,5-c']bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole (BBT), does result in materials with significantly higher electron affinity (EA) relative to BT, in many cases the extended BT systems also exhibit lower ionization energy (IE) than BT. Both the significantly higher EA and lower IE limit the efficacy of these materials in applications such as bulk heterojunction org. photovoltaics (BHJ-OPV) based on C60. Although the relatively high EA may enable some applications such as air stable org. field effect transistors (OFET), more widespread use of heteroannulated BT acceptors will likely require the ability to moderate or retain the high EA while increasing IE.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1yltbzK&md5=843e9582cce834180e6ae22f18ad28d9
      (f) Neto, B. A. D.; Carvalho, P. H. P. R.; Correa, J. R. Acc. Chem. Res. 2015, 48, 1560– 1569 DOI: 10.1021/ar500468p
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16f
      Benzothiadiazole Derivatives as Fluorescence Imaging Probes: Beyond Classical Scaffolds
      Neto, Brenno A. D.; Carvalho, Pedro H. P. R.; Correa, Jose R.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2015), 48 (6), 1560-1569CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. This Account describes the origins, features, importance, and trends of the use of fluorescent small-mol. 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (BTD) derivs. as a new class of bioprobes applied to bioimaging analyses of several (live and fixed) cell types. BTDs have been successfully used as probes for a plethora of biol. analyses for only a few years, and the impressive responses obtained by using this important class of heterocycle are fostering the development of new fluorescent BTDs and expanding the biol. applications of such derivs. The first use of a fluorescent small-mol. BTD deriv. as a selective cellular probe dates back to 2010, and since then impressive advances have been described by the authors and others. The known limitations of classical scaffolds urged the development of new classes of bioprobes. Although great developments have been achieved by using classical scaffolds such as coumarins, BODIPYs, fluoresceins, rhodamines, cyanines, and phenoxazines, there is still much to be done, and BTDs aim to succeed where these dyes showed their limitations. Important organelles and cell components such as nuclear DNA, mitochondria, lipid droplets, and others have already been successfully labeled by fluorescent small-mol. BTD derivs. New technol. systems that use BTDs as the fluorophores for bioimaging expts. have been described in recent scientific literature. The successful application of BTDs as selective bioprobes led some groups to explore their potential for use in studying membrane pores or tumor cells under hypoxic conditions. Finally, BTDs have also been used as fluorescent tags to study the action mechanism of some antitumor compds. The attractive photophys. data typically obsd. for π-extended BTD derivs. is fostering interest in the use of this new class of bioprobes. Large Stokes shifts, large molar absorptivities, high quantum yields, high stability when stored in soln. or as pure solids, no fading even after long periods of irradn., bright emissions with no blinking, good signal-to-noise ratios, efficiency to transpose the cell membrane, and irradn. preferentially in the visible-light region are just some features noted by using BTDs. As the pioneering group in the use of fluorescent small-mol. BTDs for bioimaging purposes, the authors feel pleased to share the authors' experience, results, advances, and personal perspectives with the readers of this Account. The readers will clearly note the huge advantages of using fluorescent BTDs over classical scaffolds, and hopefully they will be inspired and motivated to further BTD technol. in the fields of mol. and cellular biol.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosFGrtrY%253D&md5=ccac736fa242dc4c07184236cc335874
    17. 17
      (a) Espinet, P.; Echavarren, A. M. The mechanisms of the stille reaction Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 4704– 4734 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200300638
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17a
      C-C coupling: The mechanisms of the Stille reaction
      Espinet, Pablo; Echavarren, Antonio M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (36), 4704-4734CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Eighteen years ago in Angewandte Chemie John K. Stille reviewed a novel methodol., which eventually became known by his name, for the coupling of organostannanes with org. electrophiles. The mechanism of the consecutive steps of the reaction, oxidative addn. of org. electrophile to Pd(0) complex, transmetalation, reductive elimination of biaryls are reviewed. Role of side reactions, such as scrambling of substituents and homocoupling is also considered. Effects of bidentate ligands, anions and palladium precursors is illustrated with several examples. Mechanism of transmetalation, including isolation of stable diorganopalladium species, enhancement of stannane reactivity by fluoride and hydroxide anions, is described in details. Very recent modifications are making synthetic wishes come true that were only dreamed of a few years ago. So-called "copper effect" ascribes the acceleration of the coupling reaction either to free phosphine scavenging by added CuI, or Sn-Cu transmetalation prior to formation of diorganopalladium intermediate. Use of N-heterocyclic carbenes as ligands allows substantial improvement in chemoselectivity and activity of palladium catalysts, suppressing undesired homocoupling and accelerating the reductive elimination step. In some cases, the Stille coupling proceeds via oxidative addn. of alkynylstannanes with Pd(0) complexes, with subsequent substitution of Pd-bound organotin group by aryl ligand. Moreover, as important advances are being made in the understanding of the mechanistic details of the process, it is becoming increasingly possible to apply this essential reaction and its new variants in a less empirical way.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXotVGis7g%253D&md5=32481a2c7e9cb4003f3586e484c71e55
      (b) Suzuki, A. Carbon-carbon bonding made easy Chem. Commun. 2005, 38, 4759– 4763 DOI: 10.1039/b507375h
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (c) Sonar, P.; Singh, S. P.; Sudhakar, S.; Dodabalapur, A.; Sellinger, A. High-mobility organic thin film transistors based on benzothiadiazole-sandwiched dihexylquaterthiophenes Chem. Mater. 2008, 20, 3184– 3190 DOI: 10.1021/cm800139q
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17c
      High-Mobility Organic Thin Film Transistors Based on Benzothiadiazole-Sandwiched Dihexylquaterthiophenes
      Sonar, Prashant; Singh, Samarendra P.; Sudhakar, Sundarraj; Dodabalapur, Ananth; Sellinger, Alan
      Chemistry of Materials (2008), 20 (9), 3184-3190CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors report here the synthesis, characterization, and org. thin-film transistor (OTFT) mobilities of 4,7-bis(5-(5-hexylthiophen-2-yl)thiophen-2-yl)benzo[1,2,5]thiadiazole (DH-BTZ-4T). DH-BTZ-4T was prepd. in one high-yield step from com. available materials using Suzuki chem. and purified by column chromatog. OTFTs with hole mobilities of 0.17 cm2/(Vs) and on/off current ratios of 1 × 105 were prepd. from DH-BTZ-4T active layers deposited by vacuum deposition. As DH-BTZ-4T is sol. in common solvents, soln. processed devices were also prepd. by spin coating yielding preliminary mobilities of 6.0 × 10-3 cm2/(Vs). The promising mobilities and low band gap (1.90 eV) coupled with soln. processability and ambient stability makes this material an excellent candidate for application in org. electronics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXkslChs78%253D&md5=f6389dd34582d17ebabb45b463458fe8
      (d) Zhu, W. H.; Meng, X. L.; Yang, Y. H.; Zhang, Q.; Xie, Y. S.; Tian, H. Bisthienylethenes containing a benzothiadiazole unit as a bridge: photochromic performance dependence on substitution position Chem. - Eur. J. 2010, 16, 899– 906 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200901855
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17d
      Bisthienylethenes Containing a Benzothiadiazole Unit as a Bridge: Photochromic Performance Dependence on Substitution Position
      Zhu, Weihong; Meng, Xianle; Yang, Yuheng; Zhang, Qiong; Xie, Yongshu; Tian, He
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (3), 899-906, S899/1-S899/23CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A conveniently synthesized photochromic compd., BTB-1 (I), contg. an unprecedented six-membered 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole unit as the center ethene bridge, possesses good photochromic performance, with a high cyclization quantum yield and moderate fatigue resistance in soln. or an organogel system. The fluorescence of I can be modulated by solvato- and photochromism. However, the analog BTB-2 (II), in which the dimethylthiophene substituents are relocated to the 5,6-positions of benzothiadiazole, does not show any detectable photochromism. To the best of knowledge, this is the first example of six-membered bridge bisthienylethenes (BTEs) in which the photochromism can be controlled by the substitution position. The photochromism difference is elucidated by the anal. of resonance structure, the Woodward-Hoffmann rule, and theor. calcns. on the ground-state potential-energy surface. In a well-ordered single-crystal state, I adopts a relatively rare parallel conformation, and forms an interesting two-dimensional structure due to the presence of multiple directional intermol. interactions, including C-H···N and C-H···S hydrogen-bonding interactions, and π-π stacking interactions. This work contributes to several aspects for developing novel photochromic BTE systems with fluorescence modulation and performances controlled by substitution position in different states (soln., organogel, and single crystal).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXos1Ggtg%253D%253D&md5=4f88dabe643c3caff181a7b3fbf63ccc
      (e) Shen, M.; Rodríguez-López, J.; Huang, J.; Liu, Q.; Zhu, X. H.; Bard, A. J. Electrochemistry and electrogenerated chemiluminescence of dithienylbenzothiadiazole derivative. differential reactivity of donor and acceptor groups and simulations of radical cation-anion and dcation-radical anion annihilations J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 13453– 13461 DOI: 10.1021/ja105282u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17e
      Electrochemistry and Electrogenerated Chemiluminescence of Dithienylbenzothiadiazole Derivative. Differential Reactivity of Donor and Acceptor Groups and Simulations of Radical Cation-Anion and Dication-Radical Anion Annihilations
      Shen, Mei; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin; Huang, Ju; Liu, Quan; Zhu, Xu-Hui; Bard, Allen J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (38), 13453-13461CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We report here the electrochem. and electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) of a red-emitting dithienylbenzothiadiazole-based mol. fluorophore (4,7-bis(4-(4-sec-butoxyphenyl)-5-(3,5-di(1-naphthyl)phenyl)thiophen-2-yl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole, 1b). 1b contains two substituted thiophene groups as strong electron donors at the ends connected directly to a strong electron acceptor, 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole, in the center. Each thiophene moiety is substituted in position 2 by 3,5-di(1-naphthyl)phenyl and in position 3 by 4-sec-butoxyphenyl. Cyclic voltammetry of 1b, with scan rate ranging from 0.05 to 0.75 V/s, shows a single one-electron redn. wave (E°red = -1.18 V vs SCE) and two nernstian one-electron oxidn. waves (E°1,ox = 1.01 V, E°2,ox = 1.24 V vs SCE). Redn. of the unsubstituted 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole center shows nernstian behavior with E°red = -1.56 V vs SCE. By comparison to a digital simulation, the heterogeneous electron-transfer rate const. for redn., kr° = 1.5 × 10-3 cm/s, is significantly smaller than those for the oxidns., ko° > 0.1 cm/s, possibly indicating that the two substituted end groups have a blocking effect on the redn. of the benzothiadiazole center. The ECL spectrum, produced by electron-transfer annihilation of the reduced and oxidized forms, consists of a single peak with max. emission at about 635 nm, consistent with the fluorescence of the parent mol. Relative ECL intensities with respect to 9,10-diphenylanthracene are 330% and 470% for the radical anion-cation and radical anion-dication annihilation, resp. Radical anion (A-·)-cation (A+·) annihilation produced by potential steps shows sym. ECL transients during anodic and cathodic pulses, while for anion (A-·)-dication (A2+·) annihilation, transient ECL shows asymmetry in which the anodic pulse is narrower than the cathodic pulse. Digital simulation of the transient ECL expts. showed that the origin of the obsd. asymmetry is asymmetry in the amt. of generated charges rather than instability of the electrogenerated species.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFWlsbzI&md5=d5507daecceb581dff3c1f166648ce10

      Benzothiadiazole-containing donor-acceptor-acceptor type organic sensitizers for solar cells with ZnO photoanodes
      Lin, Ryan Yeh-Yung; Lee, Chuan-Pei; Chen, Yung-Chung; Peng, Jia-De; Chu, Te-Chun; Chou, Hsien-Hsin; Yang, Hung-Ming; Lin, Jiann T.; Ho, Kuo-Chuan
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (99), 12071-12073CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Dye-sensitized solar cells using nanocryst. ZnO as the photoanode and a metal-free sensitizer with a benzothiadiazole entity directly connected to the 2-cyanoacrylic acid acceptor exhibited an efficiency (5.18%) higher than those using the TiO2 photoanode. Use of a hierarchical ZnO back scattering layer further improved the efficiency to 5.82%.

      A benzothiadiazole end capped donor-acceptor based small molecule for organic electronics
      Sonar, Prashant; Williams, Evan L.; Singh, Samarendra P.; Manzhos, Sergei; Dodabalapur, Ananth
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2013), 15 (40), 17064-17069CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A benzothiadiazole end-capped small mol. 3,6-bis(5-(benzo[c][1,2,5]thiadiazol-4-yl)thiophen-2-yl)-2,5-bis(2-butyloctyl)pyrrolo[3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4(2H,5H)-dione (BO-DPP-BTZ) using a fused arom. moiety DPP (at the center) is designed and synthesized. BO-DPP-BTZ is a donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) structure which possesses a band gap of 1.6 eV and exhibits a strong solid state ordering inferred from ∼120 nm red shift of the absorption maxima from soln. to thin film. Field-effect transistors using a spin coated thin film of BO-DPP-BTZ as an active layer exhibited a hole mobility of 0.06 cm2 V-1 s-1. Soln.-processed bulk heterojunction org. photovoltaics employing a blend of BO-DPP-BTZ and [70]PCBM demonstrated a power conversion efficiency of 0.9%.

      Tetrathiafulvalene-Benzothiadiazoles as Redox-Tunable Donor-Acceptor Systems: Synthesis and Photophysical Study
      Pop, Flavia; Amacher, Anneliese; Avarvari, Narcis; Ding, Jie; Daku, Latevi Max Lawson; Hauser, Andreas; Koch, Marius; Hauser, Juerg; Liu, Shi-Xia; Decurtins, Silvio
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (7), 2504-2514CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Electrochem. and photophys. anal. of new donor-acceptor systems 2 and 3, in which a benzothiadiazole (BTD) unit is covalently linked to a tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) core, have verified that the lowest excited state can be ascribed to an intramol.-charge-transfer (ICT) π(TTF)→π*(BTD) transition. Owing to better overlap of the HOMO and LUMO in the fused scaffold of compd. 3, the intensity of the ICT band is substantially higher compared to that in compd. 2. The corresponding CT fluorescence is also obsd. in both cases. The radical cation TTF+. is easily obsd. through chem. and electrochem. oxidn. by performing steady-state absorption expts. Interestingly, compd. 2 is photo-oxidized under aerobic conditions.

      (a) Yang, G.; Di, C. A.; Zhang, G. X.; Zhang, J.; Xiang, J. F.; Zhang, D. Q.; Zhu, D. Highly sensitive chemical-vapor sensor based on thin-film organic field-effect transistors with benzothiadiazole-fused-tetrathiafulvalene Adv. Funct. Mater. 2013, 23, 1671– 1676 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201202473

      19a
      Highly sensitive chemical-vapor sensor based on thin-film organic field-effect transistors with benzothiadiazole-fused-tetrathiafulvalene
      Yang, Ge; Di, Chong-an; Zhang, Guanxin; Zhang, Jing; Xiang, Junfeng; Zhang, Deqing; Zhu, Daoben
      Advanced Functional Materials (2013), 23 (13), 1671-1676CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The synthesis of a new tetrathiafulvalene deriv. with an electron-withdrawing benzothiadiazole moiety and its use in thin-film org. field-effect transistors (OFETs) are reported. Compared to reported OFETs with other TTF derivs., a high hole mobility up to 0.73 cm2 V-1 s-1, low off-current and high on/off ratio up to 105 are demonstrated. In addn., the developed OFETs show fast responsiveness toward chem. vapors of DECP (di-Et chlorophosphate) or POCl3 which are simulants of phosphate-based nerve agents. In contrast to previously reported OFET-based sensors, off-current is used as the output signal, which increases quickly upon exposure to either DECP or POCl3 vapors. High sensitivity is demonstrated toward DECP and POCl3 vapors, with concns. as low as 10 ppb being detected. These OFETs are also responsive to TNT vapor. The sensing mechanisms for the new type of OFET are discussed.

Solvent-dispersed benzothiadiazole-tetrathiafulvalene single-crystal nanowires and their application in field-effect transistors ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2013, 5, 2320– 2324 DOI: 10.1021/am3025036
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Solvent-Dispersed Benzothiadiazole-Tetrathiafulvalene Single-Crystal Nanowires and Their Application in Field-Effect Transistors
      Tucker, Neil M.; Briseno, Alejandro L.; Acton, Orb; Yip, Hin-Lap; Ma, Hong; Jenekhe, Samson A.; Xia, Younan; Jen, Alex K.-Y.
      ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2013), 5 (7), 2320-2324CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
      A new org. semiconductor (BT-TTF) based on mol. moieties of benzothiadiazole and tetrathiafulvalene was designed and synthesized, and its structure, mol. packing and charge-transporting properties were detd. Thermal properties, electrochem. behaviors, and optical absorption of this mol. were studied by using DSC/TGA, cyclic voltammetry, and UV-visible spectroscopy, resp. Its bulk and nanowire single crystals were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog., SEM, TEM, and field-effect transistors. Short intermol. S···S (3.41 Å), S···C (3.49 Å), and S···N (3.05 Å) contacts define the solid-state structure of BT-TTF single crystals which π-stack along the [100] with interplanar distances of 3.49 Å. Solvent-cast single-crystal nanowire transistors showed mobilities as large as 0.36 cm2/(V s) with current on/off ratios of 1 × 106. This study further illustrates the impact of mol. design and a demonstration of high-performance single-crystal nanowire transistors from the resulting semiconductor.

      Unsymmetrical Donor-Acceptor-Acceptor-π-Donor Type Benzothiadiazole-Based Small Molecule for a Solution Processed Bulk Heterojunction Organic Solar Cell
      Gautam, Prabhat; Misra, Rajneesh; Siddiqui, Shahbaz A.; Sharma, Ganesh D.
      ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2015), 7 (19), 10283-10292CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
      A D1-A-A'-π-D2 type (D = donor; A = acceptor) unsym. small mol. denoted as BTD3 contg. different end group donor moieties has been designed and synthesized for use as a donor in the soln. processable bulk heterojunction (BHJ) solar cell. The BTD3 exhibits a low HOMO-LUMO gap of 1.68 eV and deeper HOMO energy level (-5.5 eV). Its LUMO energy level (-3.65 eV) is compatible with the LUMO level of PC71BM to facilitate the electron transfer from BTD3 to PC71BM in the BHJ solar cell. The soln. processed BHJ solar cell with optimized BTD3:PC71BM active layer processed with THF solvent exhibited a PCE of 3.15% with Jsc = 7.45 mA/cm2, Voc = 0.94 V, and FF = 0.45. Moreover, the device with optimized concn. of 3 vol. % 1-chloronaphthalene (CN) additive, i.e., CN/THF, showed significant enhancement in PCE up to 4.61% (Jsc = 9.48 mA/cm2, Voc = 0.90 V, and FF = 0.54). The improvement in the PCE has been attributed to the appropriate nanoscale phase sepn. morphol., balance charge transport, and enhancement in the light harvesting ability of the active layer.

      20a
      Intrachain versus interchain electron transport in poly(fluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole): a quantum-chemical insight
      Van Vooren, Antoine; Kim, Ji-Seon; Cornil, Jerome
      ChemPhysChem (2008), 9 (7), 989-993CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Poly(9,9-di-n-octylfluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole) [F8BT], displays very different charge-transport properties for holes vs. electrons when comparing annealed and pristine thin films and transport parallel (intrachain) and perpendicular (interchain) to the polymer axes. The present theor. contribution focuses on the electron-transport properties of F8BT chains and compares the efficiency of intrachain vs. interchain transport in the hopping regime. The theor. results rationalize significantly lowered electron mobility in annealed F8BT thin films and the smaller mobility anisotropy (μ‖/μ.perp.) measured for electrons in aligned films (i.e. 5-7 compared to 10-15 for holes).

      Property modulation of benzodithiophene-based polymers via the incorporation of a covalently bonded novel 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole-1,2,4-oxadiazole derivative in their main chain for polymer solar cells
      Agneeswari, Rajalingam; Tamilavan, Vellaiappillai; Song, Myungkwan; Hyun, Myung Ho
      Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices (2014), 2 (40), 8515-8524CODEN: JMCCCX; ISSN:2050-7534. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two new electron accepting monomers (BBOB and BOB) contg. two serially connected different electron deficient units, such as 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole and 1,2,4-oxadiazole, were prepd. and copolymd. with electron-rich benzodithiophene (BDT) deriv. to afford polymers P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB), resp. The optical band gaps of P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB) are calcd. to be 2.32 eV and 1.99 eV, resp., and their highest occupied mol. energy levels are detd. to be -5.31 eV and -5.27 eV, resp. Each of the newly synthesized polymers, i.e.P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB), is used as an electron donor, along with PC61BM as an electron acceptor, in the prepn. of polymer solar cells (PSCs). The PSCs made with the configuration of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/P(BDT-BBOB) or P(BDT-BOB):PC61BM (1 : 2 wt%)/LiF/Al gave a max. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 1.76% and 2.46%, resp., and the device performance was further improved to 3.31% and 4.21%, resp., by simply treating the photoactive layer of PSCs with iso-Pr alc. Overall, the opto-elec. and photovoltaic properties of the two polymers are quite dependent on the configuration of the covalently bonded 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole and 1,2,4-oxadiazole units incorporated in the polymer main chain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVSmtLnO&md5=c7fa62593f7f8c18ffff8ec29c2811ba
    23. 23
      Sheldrick, G. M. A short history of SHELX Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Found. Crystallogr. 2008, A64, 112– 122 DOI: 10.1107/S0108767307043930
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Tables of bond lengths determined by x-ray and neutron diffraction. Part 2. Organometallic compounds and coordination complexes of the d- and f-block metals
      Orpen, A. Guy; Brammer, Lee; Allen, Frank H.; Kennard, Olga; Watson, David G.; Taylor, Robin
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1972-1999) (1989), (12), S1-S83CODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246.
      Av. lengths for metal-ligand bonds are reported, together with some intraligand distances, for complexes of the d- and f-block metals. Mean values are presented for 325 different bond types involving metal atoms bonded to H, B, C, N, O, F, Si, P, S, Cl, As, Se, Br, Te, or I atoms of the ligands.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXivVCmsw%253D%253D&md5=8829b3e5ab4355e84cd7dec1b00d436a
    25. 25
      DaSilveira Neto, B. A.; Lopes, A. S. A.; Ebeling, G.; Gonçalves, R. S.; Costa, V. E. U.; Quina, F. H.; Dupont, J. Photophysical and electrochemical properties of π-extended molecular 2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles Tetrahedron 2005, 61, 10975– 10982 DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2005.08.093
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Photophysical and electrochemical properties of π-extended molecular 2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles
      Da Silveira Neto, Brenno A.; Sant'Ana Lopes, Aline; Ebeling, Gunter; Goncalves, Reinaldo S.; Costa, Valentim E. U.; Quina, Frank H.; Dupont, Jairton
      Tetrahedron (2005), 61 (46), 10975-10982CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The reaction of 4,7-dibromo-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole with arylboronic acids [aryl = Ph, 1-naphthyl, 4-methoxyphenyl, 4-chlorophenyl, and 4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl] in the presence of catalytic amts. of an NCP-pincer palladacycle affords photoluminescent π-extended 4,7-diaryl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles in high yields. These 4,7-diaryl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles exhibit high fluorescent quantum yields, high electron affinities, and adequate band gap values for testing as OLEDs. 4,7-Bis(1-naphthyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole presents two different lifetimes (bi-exponential decay) due to the presence of two atropisomers. The Sonogashira coupling reaction of 4,7-diethynyl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole with the corresponding haloaryl compds. (iodobenzene, 1-bromonaphthalene, 4-iodoanisole, 4-bromo-N,N-dimethylaniline, and 2-bromopyridine) afforded the photoluminescent π-extended 4,7-bis(arylethynyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles, also in high yields. These 4,7-bis(arylethynyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles also present high fluorescent quantum yields, high electron affinities, and adequate band gap values for testing as OLEDs. The 4,7-disubstituted-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles exhibit different electrochem. behavior. The presence of the two ethynyl spacers in the benzothiadiazoles shifts the redn. potentials to less cathodic values and also results in two well-defined and distinct redn. processes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFCntr7E&md5=c8fa345968fc8fe2ebc7bebd8b9e3939

      This article references 25 other publications.

      1. 1
        (a) Yaghi, O. M.; Li, G. M.; Li, H. L. Selective binding and removal of guests in a microporous metal-organic framework Nature 1995, 378, 703– 706 DOI: 10.1038/378703a0
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1a
        Selective binding and removal of guests in a microporous metal-organic framework
        Yaghi, O. M.; Li, Guangming; Li, Hailian
        Nature (London) (1995), 378 (6558), 703-6CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        Microporous inorg. materials such as zeolites find widespread application in heterogeneous catalysis, adsorption and ion-exchange processes. The rigidity and stability of such frameworks allow for shape- and size-selective inclusion of org. mols. and ions. Analogous microporous structures based on org. building blocks have the potential for more precise rational design, through control of the shape, size and functionalization of the pores. Here we report the synthesis of a metal-org. framework designed to bind arom. guest mols. selectively. The basic building block is a sym. org. mol., which binds metal ions to form layers of the metal-org. compd. alternating with layers whose compn. is detd. by the functionalization of the starting mols. The layers create channels in which guest arom. mols. may be selectively bound. We show that the crystal lattice thus formed is thermally stable up to 350°C, even after removal of included guest mols., and that the inclusions can be selectively readsorbed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXhtVSnt7rP&md5=b0f48a6fa756cb3acc150b91b847516e
        (b) Venkataraman, D.; Gardner, G. B.; Lee, S.; Moore, J. S. Zeolite-like behavior of a coordination network J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995, 117, 11600– 11601 DOI: 10.1021/ja00151a034
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1b
        Zeolite-like Behavior of a Coordination Network
        Venkataraman, D.; Gardner, Geoffrey B.; Lee, Stephen; Moore, Jeffrey S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1995), 117 (46), 11600-1CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors report the structure of a mol.-based coordination network that reversibly loses and re-absorbs guest species without undergong a change in phase or morphol. This network is a 1:1 complex of Ag(I) triflate and tritopic ligand 1. Single crystals suitable for x-ray diffraction were obtained from C6H6 by slow cooling (monoclinic I2/a, a = 17.720 (2), b = 19.067 (2), c = 24.680 (2), β = 103.88 (2)). The 3-connected network consists of 2-dimensional sheets stacked in an ···ABCD··· sequence creating channels that run at an oblique angle to [101] (i.e., the layer normal). Crystallog., 16 mols. of C6H6 per unit cell are located in the channels, 4 of which are disordered. Thermogravimetric anal. shows 2 discrete mass losses at 110° and 145° corresponding to the mass percent of 4 and 12 C6H6 mols., resp. DSC and optical microscopy confirm that no phase change is assocd. with the 1st mass loss. The unit cell parameters of a single crystal heated to 110° for 10 min remain unchanged within the std. deviation of the original crystal. This behavior is confirmed on bulk powder samples by x-ray powder diffraction. At 145°, a solid to solid phase transition occurs concomitant with the loss of the remaining C6H6 mols. This high temp. solid phase undergoes a melting transition upon further heating to 169°. Microcryst. samples heated to 110° or 145° and subsequently cooled to room temp. reabsorb C6H6 vapor in an amt. that corresponds to the mass percent in the original, unheated sample.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXovF2gtrg%253D&md5=2f4d92d6050e15fad35f977d0a5e2281
        (c) Kondo, M.; Yoshitomi, T.; Seki, K.; Matsuzaka, H.; Kitagawa, S. Three-dimensional framework with channeling cavities for small molecules: {[M2(4,4′-bpy)3(NO3)4•x H2O}n (M = Co, Ni, Zn) Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl. 1997, 36, 1725– 1727 DOI: 10.1002/anie.199717251
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1c
        Three-dimensional framework with channeling cavities for small molecules: {[M2(4,4'-bpy)3(NO3)4]·xH2O}n (M = Co, Ni, Zn)
        Kondo, Mitsuru; Yoshitomi, Tomomichi; Seki, Kenji; Matsuzaka, Hiroyuki; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English (1997), 36 (16), 1725-1727CODEN: ACIEAY; ISSN:0570-0833. (Wiley-VCH)
        Isomorphous polymeric {[M2(4,4'-bpy)3(NO3)4]·xH2O}n (M = Co, Ni, Zn, 4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine, x = 4, 4, 2, resp.) were prepd. The crystal structure of the Co complex is reported in space group Ccca with R = 0.086. Absorption of CH4, N2 and O2 by the Co polymer was studied and no structure change was detected by XRD or repeat isotherms.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (d) Kitagawa, S.; Kitaura, R.; Noro, S.-I. Functional porous coordination polymers Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 2334– 2375 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200300610
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1d
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        The pervasive chemistry of metal-organic frameworks
        Long, Jeffrey R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
