        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslWlsLbI&md5=b26cb0dee3281034eda498a56d456324
        (e) Foster, M. E.; Azoulay, J. D.; Wong, B. M.; Allendorf, M. D. Novel metal-organic framework linkers for light harvesting applications Chem. Sci. 2014, 5, 2081– 2090 DOI: 10.1039/c4sc00333k
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9e
        Novel metal-organic framework linkers for light harvesting applications
        Foster, Michael E.; Azoulay, Jason D.; Wong, Bryan M.; Allendorf, Mark D.
        Chemical Science (2014), 5 (5), 2081-2090CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are composed of org. linkers and coordinating metals that self-assemble to form a cryst. material with tunable nanoporosity. Their synthetic modularity and inherent long-range order create opportunities for use as new functional electronic materials. Using quantum mech. computational methodologies we propose novel conjugated org. linkers that are capable of forming the same one-dimensional infinite metal-oxide secondary building units (SBUs) as the well-known IRMOF-74. This structural arrangement allows for the formation of a continuous π-π stacking network that should enable charge transport in fashion analogous to org. semiconductors. The structural and electronic properties (fundamental and optical gaps) of the isolated proposed linkers were modeled using a non-empirically tuned long-range cor. functional that leads to significantly improved results compared with exptl. benchmarks. In addn., periodic hybrid d. functional calcns. were employed to model the extended MOF systems. Our results demonstrate how the electronic properties of MOFs can be readily modified to have favorable orbital alignments with known electron acceptors that should facilitate charge transfer. The predicted properties are in good agreement with expt. (i.e. UV-Vis absorption spectra), demonstrating the power of this computational approach for MOF design.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXlsFOqs7s%253D&md5=2b43442c5d117a905d27d4bccfd7a31b
        (f) So, M. C.; Wiederrecht, G. P.; Mondloch, J. E.; Hupp, J. T.; Farha, O. K. Metal-organic framework materials for light-harvesting and energy transfer Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 3501– 3510 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC09596K
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9f
        Metal-organic framework materials for light-harvesting and energy transfer
        So, Monica C.; Wiederrecht, Gary P.; Mondloch, Joseph E.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (17), 3501-3510CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review of the emerging field of metalorg. frameworks (MOFs) for photon collection and subsequent energy transfer is presented. Discussed are examples involving MOFs for (a) light harvesting, using (i) MOF-quantum dots and mol. chromophores, (ii) chromophoric MOFs, and (iii) MOFs with light-harvesting properties, and (b) energy transfer, specifically via the (i) Forster energy transfer and (ii) Dexter exchange mechanism.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXntVSqsw%253D%253D&md5=2b14e10cc8b187a4e61090cf14f65753
        (g) Lee, D. Y.; Lim, I.; Shin, C. Y.; Patil, S. A.; Lee, W.; Shrestha, N. K.; Lee, J. K.; Han, S. H. Facile interfacial charge transfer across hole doped cobalt-based MOFs/TiO2 nano-hybrids making MOFs light harvesting active layers in solar cells J. Mater. Chem. A 2015, 3, 22669– 22676 DOI: 10.1039/C5TA07180A
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9g
        Facile interfacial charge transfer across hole doped cobalt-based MOFs/TiO2 nano-hybrids making MOFs light harvesting active layers in solar cells
        Lee, Deok Yeon; Lim, Iseul; Shin, Chan Yong; Patil, Supriya A.; Lee, Wonjoo; Shrestha, Nabeen K.; Lee, Joong Kee; Han, Sung-Hwan
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2015), 3 (45), 22669-22676CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Efficient sepn. of charges and their mobility are key challenges in metal-org. framework (MOF) based devices. In the present study, thin films of cobalt-based metal org. frameworks (MOFs) are synthesized using a layer-by-layer technique, and their elec./optoelectronic properties are studied. The as-prepd. MOF films show elec. insulating behavior, which after hole doping demonstrate p-type conduction behavior. The measured HOMO-LUMO energy states of the MOF films are found to be well matched for sensitizing TiO2, and the photoluminescence quenching expt. demonstrates a facile photoelectron transfer path from the doped frameworks to TiO2. Consequently, the doped MOFs are employed successfully as light harvesting and charge transporting active layers in a fully devised TiO2-based solar cell. Two different org. ligands viz., benzene dicarboxylic acid and naphthalenedicarboxylic acid are used to synthesize two kinds of Co-MOFs having different geometrical dimensions of unit cells and pores, and their effect on hole doping and charge transportation is studied. Under optimized conditions, the Co-MOF based device demonstrates a solar-to-elec. energy conversion efficiency of 1.12% with a short circuit current of 2.56 mA cm-2, showing promising future prospects of the application of Co-MOFs in photovoltaic devices. Further, the photovoltaic performance of the Co-MOF based device is comparatively studied with that of the previously reported Cu-MOF and Ru-MOF based similar devices, and the effect of different metal centers of MOFs on their light harvesting performance is discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1Sit7rE&md5=9934f8550ede8a2bd3f00c4c7af9f294
        (h) Han, S. B.; Warren, S. C.; Yoon, S. M.; Malliakas, C. D.; Hou, X. L.; Wei, Y. H.; Kanatzidis, M. G.; Grzybowski, B. A. Tunneling electrical connection to the interior of metal-organic frameworks J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137, 8169– 8175 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.5b03263
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9h
        Tunneling Electrical Connection to the Interior of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Han, Shuangbing; Warren, Scott C.; Yoon, Seok Min; Malliakas, Christos D.; Hou, Xianliang; Wei, Yanhu; Kanatzidis, Mercouri G.; Grzybowski, Bartosz A.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (25), 8169-8175CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are typically poor elec. conductors, which limits their uses in sensors, fuel cells, batteries, and other applications that require elec. conductive, high surface area materials. Although metal nanoclusters (NCs) are often added to MOFs, the elec. properties of these hybrid materials have not yet been explored. Adding NCs to a MOF not only imparts moderate elec. cond. to an otherwise insulating material but also renders it photoconductive, with cond. increasing by up to 4 orders of magnitude upon light irradn. Because charge transport occurs via tunneling between spatially sepd. NCs that occupy a small percent of the MOF's vol., the pores remain largely open and accessible. While these phenomena are more pronounced in single-MOF crystals (here, Rb-CD-MOFs), they are also obsd. in films of smaller MOF crystallites (MIL-53). Addnl., in the photoconductive MOFs, the effective diffusion coeffs. of electrons can match the typical values of small mols. diffusing through MOFs; this property can open new vistas for the development of MOF electrodes and, in a wider context, of electroactive and light-harvesting MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXptFaisrc%253D&md5=5eed3efc5e77099172056ebe51f3dba4
        (i) Williams, D. E.; Shustova, N. B. Metal-organic frameworks as a versatile tool to study and model energy transfer processes Chem. - Eur. J. 2015, 21, 15474– 15479 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201502334
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9i
        Metal-Organic Frameworks as a Versatile Tool To Study and Model Energy Transfer Processes
        Williams, Derek E.; Shustova, Natalia B.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (44), 15474-15479CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Development of materials with efficient and directional energy transfer (ET) could significantly modify the existing energy and material landscape. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a unique tool to address the upcoming challenges related to the enhancement of ET efficiency and directional energy transport. To harness MOFs as a versatile platform, mechanistic and structural aspects governing ET efficiency should be elucidated. In this context, the authors review ET mechanisms and structural motifs based on the recent advances achieved in MOF chem. and also highlight the possible practical applications that are enabled by these studies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsVSis73O&md5=cb11da67f027b33eb0a1d0aaf5331621
        (j) Zhang, Q. Q.; Zhang, C. K.; Cao, L. Y.; Wang, Z.; An, B.; Lin, Z. K.; Huang, R. Y.; Zhang, Z. M.; Wang, C.; Lin, W. B. Förster energy transport in metal-organic frameworks is beyond step-by-step hopping J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 5308– 5315 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b01345
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9j
        F.ovrddot.orster Energy Transport in Metal-Organic Frameworks Is Beyond Step-by-Step Hopping
        Zhang, Qiongqiong; Zhang, Cankun; Cao, Lingyun; Wang, Zi; An, Bing; Lin, Zekai; Huang, Ruiyun; Zhang, Zhiming; Wang, Cheng; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (16), 5308-5315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with light-harvesting building blocks designed to mimic photosynthetic chromophore arrays in green plants provide an excellent platform to study exciton transport in networks with well-defined structures. A step-by-step exciton random hopping model made of the elementary steps of energy transfer between only the nearest neighbors is usually used to describe the transport dynamics. Although such a nearest neighbor approxn. is valid in describing the energy transfer of triplet states via the Dexter mechanism, we found it inadequate in evaluating singlet exciton migration that occurs through the F.ovrddot.orster mechanism, which involves one-step jumping over longer distance. We measured migration rates of singlet excitons on two MOFs constructed from truxene-derived ligands and zinc nodes, by monitoring energy transfer from the MOF skeleton to a coumarin probe in the MOF cavity. The diffusivities of the excitons on the frameworks were detd. to be 1.8 × 10-2 cm2/s and 2.3 × 10-2 cm2/s, corresponding to migration distances of 43 and 48 nm within their lifetimes, resp. "Through space" energy-jumping beyond nearest neighbor accounts for up to 67% of the energy transfer rates. This finding presents a new perspective in the design and understanding of highly efficient energy transport networks for singlet excited states.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XkvVyjs7c%253D&md5=5b1054be30232d3dcc909a18b56ad55c
      10. 10
        (a) Zang, S. Q.; Su, Y.; Li, Y. Z.; Ni, Z. P.; Meng, Q. J. Assemblies of a new flexible multicarboxylate ligand and d10 metal centers toward the construction of homochiral helical coordination polymers: structures, luminescence, and NLO-active properties Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 174– 180 DOI: 10.1021/ic051502m
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10a
        Assemblies of a New Flexible Multicarboxylate Ligand and d10 Metal Centers toward the Construction of Homochiral Helical Coordination Polymers: Structures, Luminescence, and NLO-Active Properties
        Zang, Shuangquan; Su, Yang; Li, Yizhi; Ni, Zhaoping; Meng, Qingjin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (1), 174-180CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Hydro(solvo)thermal reactions between a new flexible multicarboxylate ligand of 2,2',3,3'-oxydiphthalic acid (2,2',3,3'-H4ODPA) and M(NO3)2·xH2O (M = Zn, x = 6; M = Cd, x = 4) in the presence of 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) afford two novel homochiral helical coordination polymers {[Zn2(2,2',3,3'-ODPA)(bpy)(H2O)3]·(H2O)2 for 1 and [Cd2(2,2',3,3'-ODPA)(bpy)(H2O)3]·(H2O)2 for 2}. Though having almost the same chem. formula, they have different space groups (P212121 for 1 and P21 for 2) and different bridging modes of the 2,2',3,3'-ODPA ligand. Two kinds of homochiral helixes (right-handed) are found in both 1 and 2, each of which discriminates only one kind of crystallog. nonequivalent metal atom. 1 Has a 2-dimensional metal-org. framework and can be seen as the unity of two parallel homochiral Zn1 and Zn2 helixes, in which the nodes are etheric O atoms. In contrast, 2 has a 3-dimensional metal-org. framework and consists of two partially overlapped homochiral Cd1 and Cd2 helixes in the two dimensions. Also, metal-ODPA helixes give a 2-dimensional chiral herringbone structural motif in both 1 and 2 in the two dimensions, which are further strengthened by the 2nd ligand of bpy. Bulk materials for 1 and 2 all have good 2nd-harmonic generation activity, ∼1 and 0.8 times that of urea.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1ajsrvP&md5=7b2cdf96b15129711363363195799bda
        (b) Yang, J.; Li, G. D.; Cao, J. J.; Yue, Q.; Li, G.-H.; Chen, J. S. Structural variation from 1D to 3D: effects of ligands and solvents on the construction of lead(II)-organic coordination polymers Chem. - Eur. J. 2007, 13, 3248– 3261 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200600730
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10b
        Structural variation from 1D to 3D: effects of ligands and solvents on the construction of lead(II)-organic coordination polymers
        Yang, Jin; Li, Guo-Dong; Cao, Jun-Jun; Yue, Qi; Li, Guang-Hua; Chen, Jie-Sheng
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (11), 3248-3261CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        PbII coordination polymers [Pb(ndc)(dpp)] (1), [Pb(ndc)(ptcp)]·0.5H2O (2), [Pb(ndc)(dppz)] (3), [Pb(ndc)(tcpn)2] (4), [Pb2(ndc)2(tcpp)] (5), [Pb(Hndc)2]·H2O (6), [Pb(ndc)(dma)] (7), [Pb(bdc)(dma)] (8), [Pb(trans-chdc)(H2O)] (9), and [Pb2(cis-chdc)2]·NHMe2 (10), where ndc = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate, dpp = 4,7-diphenyl-1,10-phenanthroline, ptcp = 2-phenyl-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthrene, dppz = dipyrido[3,2-a:2',3'-c]phenazine, tcpn = 2-(1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthren-2-yl)naphthol, tcpp = 4-(1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthren-2-yl)phenol, dma = N,N-dimethylacetamide, bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate, were synthesized from a hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction system by varying the ligands or the solvents. Compds. 1-5 crystallize with an N-donor chelating ligand and an arom. dicarboxylate linker. Compds. 1-4 are 1-dimensional polymers with different π-π stacking interactions, whereas compd. 5 consists of 2-dimensional layers. The structures of compds. 7, 8, and 10 are 3-dimensional frameworks formed by connection of the Pb centers by org. acid ligands. Compd. 7 is chiral although the ndc ligand is achiral, while the framework of 8 is a typical 3-dimensional (3,4)-connected net. Compd. 10 is the 1st example of PbII wheel cluster [Pb8O8] units bridged by carboxylate groups. Compd. 6 contains ID chains which are further extended to a 3-dimensional structure by π-π interactions. Compd. 9 consists of a 2-dimensional network constructed by PbII centers and trans-chdc ligands. The structural differences between 7 and 8 and between 9 and 10 indicate the importance of solvents for framework formation of the coordination polymers. By varying the solvent the cis and trans conformations of H2chdc in 9 and 10 were sepd. completely. The photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties of the coordination polymers also were studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        10c
        Porous Nonlinear-Optical Material Based on a Twin-Nest-Shaped Heterothiometallic Cluster: {[NH4][W2O2S6Cu6I3(4,4'-bipy)4]·5H2O}n
        Huang, Kexuan; Song, Yinglin; Pan, Zhaorui; Li, Yizhi; Zhuo, Xin; Zheng, Hegen
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 46 (16), 6233-6235CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel 3-dimensional porous coordination complex, {[NH4][W2O2S6Cu6I3(4,4'-bipy)4]·5H2O}n, based on a twin-nest-shaped heterothiometallic cluster was synthesized and characterized. The complex shows an unprecedented structure type and interesting nonlinear-optical properties. Its gas sorption property was studied and is comparable to that of previously reported metal-org. frameworks.

        10d
        [PyH][{TpMo(μ3-S)4Cu3}4(μ12-I)]: a unique tetracubane cluster derived from the S-S bond cleavage and the iodide template effects and its enhanced NLO performances
        Wei, Zhen-Hong; Ni, Chun-Yan; Li, Hong-Xi; Ren, Zhi-Gang; Sun, Zhen-Rong; Lang, Jian-Ping

        Reactions of [Et4N][TpMoS(S4)] with three equiv. of CuI in MeCN or in pyridine gave rise to one dicubane and one tetracubane anionic clusters, [Et4N]2[{TpMo(μ3-S)3Cu3I}2(μ-I){Cu(μ-I)2(μ4-I)2}] and [PyH][{TpMo(μ3-S)4Cu3}4(μ12-I)], and their third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) responses were greatly enhanced relative to that of the precursor.

        10e
        Assembly of new Mo/Cu/S clusters from [Et4N][Tp*MoS(S4)] and Cu(I) salts: syntheses, structures and third-order nonlinear optical properties
        Zhang, Zhi-Yuan; Gong, Wei-Jie; Wang, Fan; Chen, Min-Min; Zhou, Li-Kuan; Ren, Zhi-Gang; Sun, Zhen-Rong; Lang, Jian-Ping
        Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (26), 9495-9504CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Reactions of [Et4N][Tp*MoS(S)4] [Tp* = hydridotris(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)borate] (1) with 3 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I, CN) or [Cu(MeCN)4]ClO4 in CH2Cl2-MeCN or CH2Cl2-DMF afforded [Et4N]2[Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3(CuCl)3(μ3-Cl)] (2), [Et4N][Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3(CuX)3] (3: X = Br; 4: X = I), [Et4N][Tp*MoO(μ-S)2(CuX)] (5: X = I; 6: X = CN) and [Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3Cu3(μ3-S')]4 (7). Compds. 2-7 were characterized by elemental anal., IR spectra, UV-visible spectra, 1H NMR, electrospray ion mass spectra (ESI-MS) and x-ray crystallog. The cluster dianion of 2 has a complete cubane-like [Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3(CuCl)3(μ3-Cl)] structure while the anion of 3 or 4 consists of an incomplete cubane-like [Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3(CuX)3] structure. The anion of 5 or 6 has a binuclear structure, in which one [Tp*MoO(μ-S)2] moiety and one CuX unit are linked by a pair of μ-S atoms. The structure of 7 may be considered as a supercube whose eight corners are occupied by four incomplete cubane-like [Tp*Mo(μ3-S)3Cu3] fragments and four μ3-S' atoms. The 3rd-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 2-6 in DMF were studied by femtosecond degenerate four-wave mixing (DFWM) technique with a 80 fs pulse width at 800 nm. Compds. 2-6 exhibited good NLO performances and their NLO responses were enhanced relative to that of 1.

        10f
        Gas Sorption, Second-Order Nonlinear Optics, and Luminescence Properties of a Multifunctional srs-Type Metal-Organic Framework Built by Tris(4-carboxylbiphen-1-yl)amine
        He, Yan-Ping; Tan, Yan-Xi; Zhang, Jian

        A chiral 8-fold interpenetrating srs-type metalorg. framework Zn2(TPA)(H2O)2.NO3.EtOH.2DEF (FIR-28; H3TPA = tris(4-carboxylbiphen-1-yl)amine; EtOH = ethanol; DEF = N,N-diethylformamide; FIR denotes Fujian Inst. of Res.) exhibits a surface area of 1029 m2/g and high C3H8/CH4 sepn. capacity >154 and displays strong powder 2nd-harmonic-generation efficiency, with more than half over KDP powder. The luminescence of FIR-28 is dependent on the solvent guests.

        10g
        Tetrazine Chromophore-Based Metal-Organic Frameworks with Unusual Configurations: Synthetic, Structural, Theoretical, Fluorescent, and Nonlinear Optical Studies
        Li, Jianghua; Jia, Ding; Meng, Suci; Zhang, Jinfang; Cifuentes, Marie P.; Humphrey, Mark G.; Zhang, Chi
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (21), 7914-7926CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Three unusual three-dimensional (3D) tetrazine chromophore-based metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) {(Et4N)[WS4Cu3(CN)2(4,4'-pytz)0.5]}n (1), {[MoS4Cu4(CN)2(4,4'-pytz)2]·CH2Cl2}n (2), and {[WS4Cu3(4,4'-pytz)3]·[N(CN)2]}n (3; 4,4'-pytz = 3,6-bis(4-pyridyl)tetrazine) have been synthesized and characterized by using FTIR and UV/visible spectroscopy, elemental anal., powder x-ray diffraction, gel permeation chromatog., steady-state fluorescence, and TGA; their identities were confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. MOF 1 possesses the first five-connected M/S/Cu (M = Mo, W) framework with an unusual 3D (44·66) topol. constructed from T-shaped [WS4Cu3]+ clusters as nodes and single CN-/4,4'-pytz bridges as linkers. MOF 2 features a novel 3D MOF structure with (420·68) topol., in which the bridging 4,4'-pytz ligands exhibit unique distorted arch structures. MOF 3 displays the first 3D MOF structure based on flywheel-shaped [WS4Cu3]+ clusters with a non-interpenetrating honeycomb-like framework and a heavily distorted "ACS" topol. Steady-state fluorescence studies of 1-3 reveal significant fluorescence emissions. The nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1-3 were investigated by using a Z-scan technique with 5 ns pulses at λ = 532 nm. The Z-scan exptl. results show that the π-delocalizable tetrazine-based 4,4'-pytz ligands contribute to the strong third-order NLO properties exhibited by 1-3. Time-dependent d. functional theory studies afforded insight into the electronic transitions and spectral characterization of these functionalized NLO mol. materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXmsF2jt7k%253D&md5=9ef6a010221096cdc580595339dd06b0
        (h) Liu, M.; Quah, H. S.; Wen, S. C.; Yu, Z. S.; Vittal, J. J.; Ji, W. Efficient third harmonic generation in a metal-organic framework Chem. Mater. 2016, 28, 3385– 3390 DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b00632
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10h
        Efficient Third Harmonic Generation in a Metal-Organic Framework
        Liu, Min; Quah, Hong Sheng; Wen, Shuangchun; Yu, Zhangshou; Vittal, Jagadese J.; Ji, Wei
        Chemistry of Materials (2016), 28 (10), 3385-3390CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        An efficient coherent up-conversion via 3rd harmonic generation (THG) in a Zn trans,trans-9,10-bis(4-pyridylethenyl)anthracene (An2Py) trans-4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid metalorg. framework (MOF) was obsd. It is achieved by using a MOF with a constituent ligand that possesses significant 3rd-order nonlinear optical (NLO) responses. The THG measurements at fundamental wavelengths of 1200-1600 nm show that the MOF constructed with the An2Py ligand exhibits an effective χ(3) value that is 3 orders of magnitude greater than α-SiO2. The findings demonstrate a new avenue to realize efficient 3rd-order NLO responses by using MOFs consisting of strong 3rd-order NLO ligands.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmsFOmsLY%253D&md5=d1b32eeb53839dc9647ce0e2642db0af
        (i) Zhang, W. H.; Ren, Z. G.; Lang, J. P. Rational construction of functional molybdenum (tungsten)-copper-sulfur coordination oligomers and polymers from preformed cluster precursors Chem. Soc. Rev. 2016, 45, 4995– 5019 DOI: 10.1039/C6CS00096G
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10i
        Rational construction of functional molybdenum (tungsten)-copper-sulfur coordination oligomers and polymers from preformed cluster precursors
        Zhang, Wen-Hua; Ren, Zhi-Gang; Lang, Jian-Ping
        Chemical Society Reviews (2016), 45 (18), 4995-5019CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The investigation of heterometallic Mo(W)-M'-S clusters (M' = transition metals) has its genesis in the late 1970s with the identification of the nitrogenase iron-molybdenum cofactor (FeMoco) featuring a Mo-Fe-S double-cubane cluster core. This has led to the generation of a library of cluster skeletons subsequently used as building blocks for oligomers (OGs) and polymers, merging this field with the fascinating developments in supramol. chem. and coordination polymers (CPs). While resembling the general metal-ligand assembly to form CPs in one-pot, cluster-based OGs or CPs are conventionally prepd. from Mo(W)-S synthons and Cu(I) salts in the presence of bridging ligands. This review summarizes the synthesis of Mo(W)-Cu-S cluster-supported OGs and CPs through a two-step strategy involving preformed clusters. This stepwise approach facilitates clean conversion, and is amenable to exquisite design protocols and yields products otherwise inaccessible via a direct one-pot method. We review the synthesis of OGs and CPs by cluster core upgrading, downgrading, ligand substitution, and cluster aggregation reactions, together with the optical and host-guest properties of the products. In doing so, we demonstrate the power and generality of this strategy for assembling these unique materials and offer clues on how to adapt this less practiced method to prepg. extended mol. assemblies with potentially intriguing properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnvVGru7w%253D&md5=efbc935fac4c997136c2d699b796290b
      11. 11
        (a) Kataoka, Y.; Sato, K.; Miyazaki, Y.; Masuda, K.; Tanaka, H.; Naito, S.; Mori, W. Photocatalytic hydrogen production from water using porous material [Ru2(p-BDC)2]n Energy Environ. Sci. 2009, 2, 397– 400 DOI: 10.1039/b814539c
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11a
        Photocatalytic hydrogen production from water using porous material [Ru2(p-BDC)2]n
        Kataoka, Yusuke; Sato, Konomi; Miyazaki, Yuhei; Masuda, Kazuki; Tanaka, Hiroshi; Naito, Shuichi; Mori, Wasuke
        Energy & Environmental Science (2009), 2 (4), 397-400CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        We have detected the first example of open porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that functions as an activity site for the redn. of water into hydrogen mols. in the presence of Ru(bpy)32+, MV2+, and EDTA-2Na under visible light irradn. This activity is highly efficient: the turnover no. based on MOFs and the apparent quantum yield are 8.16% and 4.82%, resp. Furthermore, this material enables the adsorption of various gases into its pores; its hydrogen uptake capacity is 1.2 wt.% at 77.4 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXnsVSmsLo%253D&md5=6b659bdd25ea12cdc5bb0b01a37c090c
        (b) Dan-Hardi, M.; Serre, C.; Frot, T.; Rozes, L.; Maurin, G.; Sanchez, C.; Férey, G. A new photoactive crystalline highly porous titanium(IV) dicarboxylate J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 10857– 10859 DOI: 10.1021/ja903726m
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11b
        A new photoactive crystalline highly porous titanium(IV) dicarboxylate
        Dan-Hardi, Meenakshi; Serre, Christian; Frot, Theo; Rozes, Laurence; Maurin, Guillaume; Sanchez, Clement; Ferey, Gerard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (31), 10857-10859CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Titanium is a very attractive candidate for MOFs due to its low toxicity, redox activity, and photocatalytic properties. We present here MIL-125, the first example of a highly porous and cryst. titanium(IV) dicarboxylate (MIL stands for Materials of Institut Lavoisier) with a high thermal stability and photochem. properties. Its structure is built up from a pseudo cubic arrangement of octameric wheels, built up from edge- or corner-sharing titanium octahedra, and terephthalate dianions leading to a three-dimensional periodic array of two types of hybrid cages with accessible pore diams. of 6.13 and 12.55 Å. X-ray thermodiffractometry and thermal anal. show that MIL-125 is stable up to 360 ° under air atm. while nitrogen sorption anal. indicates a surface area (BET) of 1550 m2/g-1. Moreover, under nitrogen and alc. adsorption, MIL-125 exhibits a photochromic behavior assocd. with the formation of stable mixed valence titanium-oxo compds. The titanium oxo cluster are back oxidized in the presence of oxygen. This photochem. phenomenon is analyzed through the combined use of ESR and UV-visible absorption spectroscopies. The photogenerated electrons are trapped as Ti(III) centers, while a concomitant oxidn. of the adsorbed alc. mols. occurs. This new microporous hybrid is a very promising candidate for applications in smart photonic devices, sensors, and catalysis.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXovVeltbc%253D&md5=6ccc223f9145f3c4c0f5daf02cb2850c
        (c) deKrafft, K. E.; Wang, C.; Lin, W. B. Metal-organic framework templated synthesis of Fe2O3/TiO2 nanocomposite for hydrogen production Adv. Mater. 2012, 24, 2014– 2018 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201200330
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11c
        Metal-Organic Framework Templated Synthesis of Fe2O3/TiO2 Nanocomposite for Hydrogen Production
        deKrafft, Kathryn E.; Wang, Cheng; Lin, Wenbin
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2012), 24 (15), 2014-2018CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Here we report a simple, inexpensive, tunable, and scalable metal-org. framework (MOF)-templated strategy for the synthesis of a mixed metal oxide nanocomposite with useful photophys. properties. Although MOFs have been explored for a wide range of applications such as nonlinear optics, gas storage, catalysis chem. sensing, and drug delivery, there have been only a few reports on using MOFs as templates in the synthesis of silica nanoshells, nanoporous carbon, and metallic nanoparticles. In this work, we attempt to use nanoscale MOFs to prep. titania-based nanocomposites for potential solar energy applications. Fe-contg. nanoscale MOFs are coated with amorphous titania, then calcined to produce cryst. Fe2O3(S)TiO2 composite nanoparticles, which enable visible light-driven hydrogen prodn. from water.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (f) Wang, C.; DeKrafft, K. E.; Lin, W. B. Pt nanoparticles@photoactive metal-organic frameworks: efficient hydrogen evolution via synergistic photoexcitation and electron injection J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 7211– 7214 DOI: 10.1021/ja300539p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11f
        Pt Nanoparticles@Photoactive Metal-Organic Frameworks: Efficient Hydrogen Evolution via Synergistic Photoexcitation and Electron Injection
        Wang, Cheng; deKrafft, Kathryn E.; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (17), 7211-7214CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Pt nanoparticles of 2-3 nm and 5-6 nm in diam. were loaded into stable, porous, and phosphorescent metal-org. frameworks (MOFs 1 and 2) built from [Ir(ppy)2(bpy)]+-derived dicarboxylate ligands (L1 and L2) and Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(carboxylate)12 secondary building units, via MOF-mediated photoredn. of K2PtCl4. The resulting Pt@MOF assemblies serve as effective photocatalysts for H evolution by synergistic photoexcitation of the MOF frameworks and electron injection into the Pt nanoparticles. Pt@2 gave a turnover no. of 7000, approx. five times the value afforded by the homogeneous control, and could be readily recycled and reused.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xlt1Smt7c%253D&md5=949038bfb16b89cb9d821e1781078808
        (g) Zhou, T. H.; Du, Y. H.; Borgna, A.; Hong, J. D.; Wang, Y. B.; Han, J. Y.; Zhang, W.; Xu, R. Post-synthesis modification of a metal-organic framework to construct a bifunctional photocatalyst for hydrogen production Energy Environ. Sci. 2013, 6, 3229– 3234 DOI: 10.1039/c3ee41548a
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11g
        Post-synthesis modification of a metal-organic framework to construct a bifunctional photocatalyst for hydrogen production
        Zhou, Tianhua; Du, Yonghua; Borgna, Armando; Hong, Jindui; Wang, Yabo; Han, Jianyu; Zhang, Wei; Xu, Rong
        Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (11), 3229-3234CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        To construct photocatalytically active MOFs, various strategies have recently been developed. The authors have synthesized and characterized a new metal-org. framework (MOF-253-Pt) material through immobilizing a platinum complex in 2,2'-bipyridine-based microporous MOF (MOF-253) using a post-synthesis modification strategy. The functionalized MOF-253-Pt serves both as a photosensitizer and a photocatalyst for hydrogen evolution under visible-light irradn. The photocatalytic activity of MOF-253-Pt is approx. five times higher than that of the corresponding complex. The presence of the short Pt···Pt interactions in the framework was revealed with extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy and low temp. luminescence. These interactions play an important role in improving the photocatalytic activity of the resulting MOF.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1KqtrbK&md5=f9d2942c8e46e4548440521ae3920f5b
      12. 12
        (a) Meng, W.; Xu, Z. Q.; Ding, J.; Wu, D. Q.; Han, X.; Hou, H. W.; Fan, Y. T. A systematic research on the synthesis, structures, and application in photocatalysis of cluster-based coordination complexes Cryst. Growth Des. 2014, 14, 730– 738 DOI: 10.1021/cg401601d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12a
        A Systematic Research on the Synthesis, Structures, and Application in Photocatalysis of Cluster-Based Coordination Complexes
        Meng, Wei; Xu, Zhouqing; Ding, Jie; Wu, Dongqing; Han, Xiao; Hou, Hongwei; Fan, Yaoting
        Crystal Growth & Design (2014), 14 (2), 730-738CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        To search for effective photocatalysts in the field of cluster-based coordination complexes, the authors synthesized {[Cd2(dcpp)(beb)2 (H2O)]·H2O}n (1), [Cd2(dcpp)(bmb)(H2O)2]n (2), {[Cd2(dcpp)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2]·2H2O}n (3), and {[Cd2(dcpp)(4,4'-bipy)0.5(H2O)3]·H2O}n (4) by using a butterfly-shaped multidentate carboxylic acid (4,5-di-(4'-carboxyl-phenyl)-phthalic acid) (H4dcpp) and N-donor ligands (1,4-bis-(2-ethyl-benz-imidazol-1-ylmethyl)) benzene (beb), 1,4-bis-(2-methyl-benz-imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene (bmb), 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bipy), 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy). Complexes 1-4 are constructed based on different SBUs. Complexes 1 and 2 possess three-dimensional (3D) pillar-layered frameworks based on noncluster-type SBUs and dinuclear Cd2 clusters units, resp. Complex 3 is a 3D porous structure building on Cd4 clusters SBUs. Complex 4 is constructed from rare infinite botryoid-like Cd cluster chains and exhibits a 3D complicated framework. The research on optical energy gaps of complexes 1-4 indicates that these complexes are potential semiconductive materials. Moreover, complexes 1-4 are applied to catalyze the reaction of photocatalytic degrdn. of methylene orange (MO) under high-pressure mercury lamp irradn. Excitingly, they exhibit good photocatalytic properties in the presence of H2O2, and the degrdn. rates for 1-4 increase from 43% (without photocatalyst) to 97, 78, 85, and 67%, resp., after 100 min of irradn. The photoluminescent properties of complexes 1-4 were also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXktlemtA%253D%253D&md5=ea6f16ca21d559505cd32635d2903c57
        (b) Li, R.; Ren, X. Q.; Ma, H. W.; Feng, X.; Lin, Z. G.; Li, X. G.; Hu, C. W.; Wang, B. Nickel-substituted zeolitic imidazolate frameworks for time-resolved alcohol sensing and photocatalysis under visible light J. Mater. Chem. A 2014, 2, 5724– 5729 DOI: 10.1039/c3ta15058e
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12b
        Nickel-substituted zeolitic imidazolate frameworks for time-resolved alcohol sensing and photocatalysis under visible light
        Li, Rui; Ren, Xiaoqian; Ma, Hongwei; Feng, Xiao; Lin, Zhengguo; Li, Xingguo; Hu, Changwen; Wang, Bo
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2014), 2 (16), 5724-5729CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A facile strategy has been developed to introduce six-coordinated nickel clusters into a zinc-based ZIF-8 structure via a one-pot mechanochem. synthesis under liq. assisted grinding (LAG) conditions. This Ni-substituted ZIF-8, denoted as BIT-11, can selectively pick different alc. mols. according to their shapes and undergo a de-coordination to form stable four-coordinated Ni clusters denoted as BIT-11b. Alternatively single crystals of Ni-substituted ZIF-8 with a similar coordination environment to BIT-11b are synthesized solvothermally. BIT-11b also shows exceptional photocatalytic activity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXltFWqsLk%253D&md5=738a0e6009d68ea54e0bc2e85f1bb324
        (c) Kong, X. J.; Lin, Z. K.; Zhang, Z. M.; Zhang, T.; Lin, W. B. Hierarchical integration of photosensitizing metal-organic frameworks and nickel-containing polyoxometalates for efficient visible-light-driven hydrogen evolution Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 6411– 6416 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201600431
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12c
        Hierarchical Integration of Photosensitizing Metal-Organic Frameworks and Nickel-Containing Polyoxometalates for Efficient Visible-Light-Driven Hydrogen Evolution
        Kong, Xiang-Jian; Lin, Zekai; Zhang, Zhi-Ming; Zhang, Teng; Lin, Wenbin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (22), 6411-6416CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) provide a tunable platform for hierarchically integrating multiple components to effect synergistic functions that cannot be achieved in soln. Here the authors report the encapsulation of a Ni-contg. polyoxometalate (POM) [Ni4(H2O)2(PW9O34)2]10- (Ni4P2) into 2 highly stable and porous phosphorescent MOFs. The proximity of Ni4P2 to multiple photosensitizers in Ni4P2@MOF allows for facile multi-electron transfer to enable efficient visible-light-driven H evolution reaction (HER) with turnover nos. ≤1476. Photophys. and electrochem. studies established the oxidative quenching of the excited photosensitizer by Ni4P2 as the initiating step of HER and explained the drastic catalytic activity difference of the 2 POM@MOFs. POM@MOF assemblies not only provide a tunable platform for designing highly effective photocatalytic HER catalysts but also facilitate detailed mechanistic understanding of HER processes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xmt1ertLY%253D&md5=93f1520d2ee7838da3553a999e36a898
        (d) Chen, D. S.; Xing, H. Z.; Wang, C. G.; Su, Z. M. Highly efficient visible-light-driven CO2 reduction to formate by a new anthracene-based zirconium MOF via dual catalytic routes J. Mater. Chem. A 2016, 4, 2657– 2662 DOI: 10.1039/C6TA00429F
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12d
        Highly efficient visible-light-driven CO2 reduction to formate by a new anthracene-based zirconium MOF via dual catalytic routes
        Chen, Dashu; Xing, Hongzhu; Wang, Chungang; Su, Zhongmin
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (7), 2657-2662CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new microporous robust zirconium metal-org. framework (Zr-MOF), NNU-28, has been synthesized and employed as a visible-light photocatalyst for carbon dioxide (CO2) redn. to produce formate. NNU-28 is constructed by using a visible light responsive org. ligand derived from an anthracene group. Studies reveal that the as-prepd. Zr-MOF shows desirable characteristics including excellent chem. and thermal stability, high CO2 uptake, broad-band visible light absorption and efficient photoinduced charge generation. Remarkably, NNU-28 is highly efficient for visible-light-driven CO2 redn. with a formate formation rate of 183.3 μmol h-1 mmolMOF-1, which is among the highest performances of Zr-MOFs. Both photocatalytic expts. and ESR (EPR) studies reveal that both the inorg. building unit Zr6 oxo cluster and the anthracene-based ligand contribute to the highly efficient photocatalysis of CO2 redn. The dual photocatalytic routes are demonstrated here to be more efficient for visible-light-driven CO2 photoredn. than that typically relying on a ligand-to-metal charge transfer process, illustrating a new strategy to design and synthesize novel visible-light photocatalysts for CO2 redn. with high efficiency.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhslWnsbk%253D&md5=2347b48012be5b22d12b6522183a61ca

        13a
        Coordination Polymers Containing 1D Channels as Selective Luminescent Probes
        Zhao, Bin; Chen, Xiao-Yan; Cheng, Peng; Liao, Dai-Zheng; Yan, Shi-Ping; Jiang, Zong-Hui
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (47), 15394-15395CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two 3d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers {[Ln(PDA)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]·3.25H2O}∞ with 1-dimensional channels were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions (H2PDA = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid; Ln = Eu (1); Ln = Tb (2)). The emission intensities of 1 and 2 increased significantly upon addn. of Zn2+, while the introduction of other metal ions caused the intensity to be either unchanged or weakened. The case implies that 1 and 2 may be used as luminescent probes of Zn2+. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 2 were also investigated.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptlSisrg%253D&md5=bb41702a1cd33b4d7a5fae232cbca634

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13b
        Multifunctionality and Crystal Dynamics of a Highly Stable, Porous Metal-Organic Framework [Zn4O(NTB)2]
        Lee, Eun Young; Jang, Seung Yeon; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (17), 6374-6381CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A porous metal-org. framework [Zn4O(NTB)2]·3DEF·EtOH (1), in which (3,6)-connected nets are doubly interpenetrated to generate curved three-dimensional channels, was prepd. Framework 1 exhibits high permanent porosity (Langmuir surface area, 1121 m2/g; pore vol., 0.51 cm3/cm3), high thermal stability (up to 430°), high H adsorption capacity (1.9% at 77 K and 1 atm), selective org. guest binding ability (Kf: MeOH > pyridine > benzene > dodecane), and guest-dependent blue luminescence (λmax depending on guest identity). Most interestingly, the framework sustains single crystallinity even at 400° and 10-5 Torr, and the framework components undergo reversible dynamics, mainly rotational motion, in response to removal and rebinding of the guest mols.

        (c) Zhu, W.-H.; Wang, Z.-M.; Gao, S. Two 3D porous lanthanide-fumarate-oxalate frameworks exhibiting framework dynamics and luminescent change upon reversible deand rehydration Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 1337– 1342 DOI: 10.1021/ic061833e
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13c
        Two 3D Porous Lanthanide-Fumarate-Oxalate Frameworks Exhibiting Framework Dynamics and Luminescent Change upon Reversible De- and Rehydration
        Zhu, Wen-Hua; Wang, Zhe-Ming; Gao, Song
        Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (4), 1337-1342CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors present two porous luminescent compds., [Ln2(fumarate)2(oxalate)(H2O)4]·4H2O (Ln = Eu, Tb), prepd. by the hydrothermal method. The materials have 3-dimensional framework structure consisting of oxalate pillared lanthanide-fumarate layers with intersected channels occupied by guest H2O. They exhibit framework dynamics upon several cycles of dehydration and rehydration. The crystallinity of the as-prepd. hydrated materials degrades completely to the amorphous dehydrated phases, while it returns upon rehydration. A mechanism for de-/rehydration is proposed from the structure and spectroscopic data. The dehydration process is accompanied by the lost of luminescence of Ln ion, but the luminescence is recovered upon rehydration, where H2O mols. in fact enhance the luminescence but not quench it. This is probably due to the softened environment of lanthanide ion in the dehydrated amorphous phases and the recovery of the stiffness after rehydration.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltlamtg%253D%253D&md5=f640834977487441ec89f1c12817856d

        Three-Dimensional Lanthanide Anionic Metal-Organic Frameworks with Tunable Luminescent Properties Induced by Cation Exchange

        Three 3-dimensional lanthanide anionic metal-org. frameworks, {K5[Ln5(IDC)4(ox)4]·20H2O}n, with 1-dimensional channels were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions [IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate, ox = oxalate, Ln = Gd (1), Tb (2), and Dy (3)]. The K+ ions within the 1-dimensional channel are easily exchanged with various cations. The emission intensities of TbIII in 2 increased significantly upon the addn. of Ca2+ ions, while the introduction of other metal ions caused the intensities to be either unchanged or weakened.

        A miniaturized prototype for pH sensing in the pH range 5-7.5 has been constructed from a photoluminescent Eu3+ metal-org. framework that contains two different Eu3+ sites and self-assembles through hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions. This material has a very high quantum yield and an excellent balance between absorption, energy transfer, and emission rate.

        13f
        Porous Phosphorescent Coordination Polymers for Oxygen Sensing
        Xie, Zhigang; Ma, Liqing; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Jin, Athena; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (3), 922-923CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium tris(2-phenylpyridine) derivs. were designed and incorporated into coordination polymers as tricarboxylate bridging ligands. Three different cryst. coordination polymers were synthesized using a solvothermal technique and were characterized using a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, IR spectroscopy, gas adsorption measurements, and luminescence measurements. The coordination polymer built from Ir[3-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 1, is highly porous with a nitrogen BET surface area of 764 m2/g, whereas the coordination polymers built from Ir[4-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 2 and 3, were nonporous. The 3MLCT phosphorescence of each of the three coordination polymers was quenched in the presence of O2. However, only 1 showed quick and reversible luminescence quenching by oxygen, whereas 2 and 3 exhibited gradual and irreversible luminescence quenching by oxygen. The high permanent porosity of 1 allows for rapid diffusion of oxygen through the open channels, leading to efficient and reversible quenching of the 3MLCT phosphorescence. This work highlights the opportunity of designing highly porous and luminescent coordination polymers for sensing other important analytes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1alurrL&md5=5b4db906f93aa4289f08b1946f61662e

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        (h) Ferrando-Soria, J.; Khajavi, H.; Serra-Crespo, P.; Gascon, J.; Kapteijn, F.; Julve, M.; Lloret, F.; Pasán, J.; Ruiz-Pérez, C.; Journaux, Y.; Pardo, E. Highly selective chemical sensing in a luminescent nanoporous magnet Adv. Mater. 2012, 24, 5625– 5629 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201201846

        13h
        Highly Selective Chemical Sensing in a Luminescent Nanoporous Magnet
        Ferrando-Soria, Jesus; Khajavi, Hossein; Serra-Crespo, Pablo; Gascon, Jorge; Kapteijn, Freek; Julve, Miguel; Lloret, Francesc; Pasan, Jorge; Ruiz-Perez, Catalina; Journaux, Yves; Pardo, Emilio
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2012), 24 (41), 5625-5629CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Presented are the synthesis, crystal structure, thermal and sorption behavior, optical and magnetic properties of a new manganese(II)-copper(II) 2D metal-org. framework (MOF) of formula MV[Mn2Cu3(mpba)3(H2O)3]•20H2O (1), where MV2+ is the methylviologen dicationic dye and mpba4- is the N,N'-1,3-phenylenebis(oxamate) bridging ligand. Compd. 1 exhibits highly selective gas sorption ability, luminescence capacity, and long-range magnetic ordering, constituting thus a unique example of luminescent porous magnet with potential applications in host-guest chem. sensing of small mols. The accessible porosity of the anhyd. deriv. of 1 was calcd. by means of gas adsorption isotherms at room temp. CO2 is able to enter the pores with a satn. loading of 1.5 mol kg-1 at 30 bar. Other gas mols. like CH4 or bigger hydrocarbons were not adsorbed. Challenged by the selective gas sorption results obtained by using CO2 and CH4 as analytes similar emission measurements were performed through a coating of the anhyd. deriv. of 1 under different single gases and gas mixt. atmospheres. The emission spectrum after CH4 treatment still corresponds with the one of the dehydrated framework, demonstrating that CH4 does not adsorb. In contrast, a considerable red-shift is obsd. when CO2 is adsorbed. For a CO2-CH4 mixt., the results are similar to those obtained with pure CO2. Since CH4 does not adsorb on the framework, the luminescence response to CO2 is similar as for the single gas expt., demonstrating that CO2 can be detected in the presence of non-adsorbing gases, i.e. methane.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFOmt7bE&md5=09b11d2a42cbc2a85bf2b7053f86be4e
      14. 14
        (a) Wang, J. H.; Li, M.; Li, D. A dynamic, luminescent and entangled MOF as a qualitative sensor for volatile organic solvents and a quantitative monitor for acetonitrile vapour Chem. Sci. 2013, 4, 1793– 1801 DOI: 10.1039/c3sc00016h
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14a
        A dynamic, luminescent and entangled MOF as a qualitative sensor for volatile organic solvents and a quantitative monitor for acetonitrile vapour
        Wang, Jun-Hao; Li, Mian; Li, Dan
        Chemical Science (2013), 4 (4), 1793-1801CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new luminescent entangled (srs nets with 2-fold interpenetration, linked via short Cu···Cu distances of ∼2.8 Å) MOF, namely, [(CuCN)3L·(guest)x]n (L =2,6-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)pyridine; x =1 or 2), which contains microporous channels, is synthesized. This MOF material shows structural dynamics upon adsorption of various volatile org. solvent mols., accompanied by reversible guest responsive color changes of the fluorescence emission that are discernible by the naked eyes. The vacuated form of this material can also exhibit qual. solvate-optical sensing behaviors toward various mixed solvents. A quant. real-time monitoring device is constructed that implements the detn. of acetonitrile vapor pressure through optical response, which causes a drastic emission change from blue to yellow. The detailed structural elucidation provides structure-property understanding for the host-guest responsive dynamics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjtlymsbo%253D&md5=d88aae265addfc3292c17101b21fc58d
        (b) Song, X. Z.; Song, S. Y.; Zhao, S. N.; Hao, Z. M.; Zhu, M.; Meng, X.; Wu, L. L.; Zhang, H. J. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation of a europium(III) metal-organic framework producing a multi-responsive luminescent sensor Adv. Funct. Mater. 2014, 24, 4034– 4041 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201303986
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14b
        Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Transformation of a Europium(III) Metal-Organic Framework Producing a Multi-responsive Luminescent Sensor
        Song, Xue-Zhi; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhao, Shu-Na; Hao, Zhao-Min; Zhu, Min; Meng, Xing; Wu, Lan-Lan; Zhang, Hong-Jie
        Advanced Functional Materials (2014), 24 (26), 4034-4041CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A sensor with a red-emission signal is successfully obtained by the solvothermal reaction of Eu3+ and heterofunctional ligand bpydbH2 (4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid), followed by terminal-ligand exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. As a result of treatments both before and after the metal-org. framework formation, accessible Lewis-base sites and coordinated water mols. are successfully anchored onto the host material, and they act as signal transmission media for the recognition of analytes at the mol. level. This is the 1st reported sensor based on a metal-org. framework (MOF) with multi-responsive optical sensing properties. It is capable of sensing small org. mols. and inorg. ions, and unprecedentedly it can discriminate among the homologs and isomers of aliph. alcs. as well as detect highly explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in water or in the vapor phase. This work highlights the practical application of luminescent MOFs as sensors, and it paves the way toward other multi-responsive sensors by demonstrating the incorporation of various functional groups into a single framework.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXks1Wqt70%253D&md5=1590a1dc92771564306f581f4155e753
        (c) Nickerl, G.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S. Tetrazine functionalized zirconium MOF as an optical sensor for oxidizing gases Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 2280– 2282 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC08136F
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14c
        Tetrazine functionalized zirconium MOF as an optical sensor for oxidizing gases
        Nickerl, Georg; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (12), 2280-2282CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Dihydro-1,2,4,5-tetrazine-3,6-dicarboxylate was introduced into the chem. stable UiO-66 structure by a postsynthetic linker exchange reaction to create an optical sensor material for the detection of oxidative agents such as nitrous gases. The incorporated tetrazine unit can be reversibly oxidized and reduced, which is accompanied by a drastic color change from yellow to pink and vice versa. The high stability of the framework during redox reaction was proven by powder x-ray diffraction and nitrogen physisorption measurements.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Metal-organic frameworks for luminescence thermometry
        Cui, Yuanjing; Zhu, Fengliang; Chen, Banglin; Qian, Guodong
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (35), 7420-7431CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) hold great promise for developing various types of luminescent sensors due to their remarkable structural diversity and tunable luminescence properties. In the last few years, using luminescent MOFs to explore temp. sensing has gained intense attention. In this feature article, after the general description of luminescence thermometry, the authors have summarized the recent progress made in luminescent MOF thermometers, with particular emphasis on the dual-emitting MOFs that effectively illustrate the self-referencing temp. measurement based on the intensity ratios of 2 sep. transitions.

        (e) Ye, J. W.; Zhou, H. L.; Liu, S. Y.; Cheng, X. N.; Lin, R. B.; Qi, X. L.; Zhang, J. P.; Chen, X. M. Encapsulating pyrene in a metal-organic zeolite for optical sensing of molecular oxygen Chem. Mater. 2015, 27, 8255– 8260 DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b03955
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14e
        Encapsulating Pyrene in a Metal-Organic Zeolite for Optical Sensing of Molecular Oxygen
        Ye, Jia-Wen; Zhou, Hao-Long; Liu, Si-Yang; Cheng, Xiao-Ning; Lin, Rui-Biao; Qi, Xiao-Lin; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Chemistry of Materials (2015), 27 (24), 8255-8260CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Pyrene is a good oxygen-sensitive probe with high fluorescence quantum yield, suitable sensitivity, and high photostability when dispersed in gas-permeable org. polymers, but it is a carcinogen and environmental pollutant and tends to aggregate and/or evap. at high temp./low pressure. In this work, we show that pyrene can be easily and firmly encapsulated in a metal-org. zeolite SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (Hmim = 2-methylimidazole, MAF-4 or ZIF-8) via an in situ loading strategy, giving fluorescence O2-sensing materials not only with fast response, high photostability, and tunable sensitivity but also free of pyrene aggregation/leak and interference by other quenchers. Moreover, these host-guest inclusion crystals can be easily fabricated as thin film sensors and aerodynamic coatings.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFSmtbzI&md5=d089626766af1df4735f61ced278cc8c
        (f) Zhao, J.; Wang, Y. N.; Dong, W. W.; Wu, Y. P.; Li, D. S.; Zhang, Q. C. A robust luminescent Tb(III)-MOF with lewis basic pyridyl sites for the highly sensitive detection of metal ions and small molecules Inorg. Chem. 2016, 55, 3265– 3271 DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b02294
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14f
        A Robust Luminescent Tb(III)-MOF with Lewis Basic Pyridyl Sites for the Highly Sensitive Detection of Metal Ions and Small Molecules
        Zhao, Jun; Wang, Ye-Nan; Dong, Wen-Wen; Wu, Ya-Pan; Li, Dong-Sheng; Zhang, Qi-Chun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2016), 55 (7), 3265-3271CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new luminescent terbium-metal-org. framework [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O (1) (H4L = 4,4'-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)diisophthalic acid) was successfully assembled by Tb3+ ions and an undeveloped pyridyl-tetracarboxylate. Compd. 1 exhibits a 3-dimensional porous (3,8)-connected (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topol. framework with fascinating 1-dimensional open hydrophilic channels decorated by uncoordinated Lewis basic pyridyl N atoms. In particular, the Tb-MOF (1) can detect Cu2+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity, and its luminescence is nearly entirely quenched in DMF soln. and biol. system. 1 Still has high detection for the trace content of nitromethane with 70 ppm, which suggests that 1 is a promising example of a dual functional material with sensing Cu ions and nitromethane.

        15
        Spectroscopic and Crystallographic Investigations of Novel BODIPY-Derived Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Li, Ming; Yao, Yi; Ding, Jie; Liu, Lu; Qin, Jianhua; Zhao, Yaopeng; Hou, Hongwei; Fan, Yaoting
        Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (4), 1346-1353CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        To explore new 4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (BODIPY)-derived metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), the authors employed 2,6-dicarboxyl-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-phenyl-4,4-difluoroboradiazaindacene (H2L) as a ligand to successfully synthesize five coordination polymers, namely, {[Zn2(L)2(bpp)]·2H2O·2EtOH}n (1), {[Cd2(L)2(bpp)]·2H2O·EtOH}n (2), {[Cd2(L)(bpe)3(NO3)2]·2H2O·DMF·EtOH}n (3), {[Cd(L)(bpe)0.5(DMF)(H2O)]}n (4), and {[Cd(L)(bpe)0.5]·1.5H2O·DMF}n (5) (bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane, bpe = 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane). Except for two 2D-layer coordination polymers 3 and 4, the rest samples exhibit 3D metal-org. frameworks with certain pore sizes, esp. MOFs 1 and 5. Spectroscopic and crystallog. investigations demonstrate that the absorption and emission energies of the BODIPY chromophores are sensitive to the coordination modes. Moreover, in case 2, the transition metal centers coordinated with the dicarboxylate ligands L2- are capable of forming the two BODIPY units in coplanar arrangements (θ = 37.9°), simultaneously suppressing the uncommon J-dimer absorption band centered at 705 nm with a long tail into the near-IR region at room temp. However, in comparison with the ligand H2L, the emission of monomer-like BODIPY in case 3 is enhanced in the solid state by a considerably long distance between the parallel BODIPY planes (∼14.0 Å).

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosVOrtA%253D%253D&md5=eec1579b2ae8e75808bebeda62d2fcf2
      16. 16
        (a) Chen, J. W.; Cao, Y. Development of novel conjugated donor polymers for high-efficiency bulk-heterojunction photovoltaic devices Acc. Chem. Res. 2009, 42, 1709– 1718 DOI: 10.1021/ar900061z
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16a
        Development of Novel Conjugated Donor Polymers for High-Efficiency Bulk-Heterojunction Photovoltaic Devices
        Chen, Junwu; Cao, Yong
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2009), 42 (11), 1709-1718CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Org. photovoltaic technol. is emerging as a potential competitor to silicon-based photovoltaic cells, and their power conversion efficiencies can now exceed 6%. Polymeric bulk-heterojunction photovoltaic cells, whose photoactive layer is composed of a blend of bicontinuous and interpenetrating donors and acceptors, can maximize interfacial area between the donor and the acceptor. Classic polymer donors, such as dialkoxy-substituted poly(p-phenylene vinylene)s and poly(3-hexylthiophene), have been widely investigated. However, advances in synthetic methodol. provide new avenues for the development of novel conjugated polymer donors with improved power conversion efficiencies. This paper primarily focuses on novel donor polymers that have shown power conversion efficiencies >1%. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole, thiophene, thieno[3,4-b]pyrazine, quinoxaline, and silole have emerged as useful heterocycles for constructing a variety of conjugated polymers for photovoltaic applications. We summarize useful information, such as mol. wts., absorption, bandgap, energy levels, and their photovoltaic performances with detailed device parameters, about these novel donor polymers. We use statistical summaries to evaluate several important parameter relationships among these polymer donors including open-circuit voltage vs. HOMO, power conversion efficiency vs. bandgap, and power conversion efficiency vs. hole mobility. Further statistical anal. of the data may guide further structural design and evaluation of polymer donor materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotVGktrs%253D&md5=608eed761b19d5f4630af5844480b630
        (b) Beaujuge, P. M.; Amb, C. M.; Reynolds, J. R. Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions Acc. Chem. Res. 2010, 43, 1396– 1407 DOI: 10.1021/ar100043u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16b
        Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions
        Beaujuge, Pierre M.; Amb, Chad M.; Reynolds, John R.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2010), 43 (11), 1396-1407CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. With the development of light-harvesting org. materials for solar cell applications and mol. systems with fine-tuned colors for nonemissive electrochromic devices (e.g., smart windows, e-papers), a no. of tech. challenges remain to be overcome. Over the years, the concept of "spectral engineering" (tailoring the complex interplay between mol. physics and the various optical phenomena occurring across the electromagnetic spectrum) has become increasingly relevant in the field of π-conjugated org. polymers. Within the spectral engineering toolbox, the "donor-acceptor" approach uses alternating electron-rich and electron-deficient moieties along a π-conjugated backbone. This approach has proved esp. valuable in the synthesis of dual-band and broadly absorbing chromophores with useful photovoltaic and electrochromic properties. In this Account, we highlight and provide insight into a present controversy surrounding the origin of the dual band of absorption sometimes encountered in semiconducting polymers structured using the "donor-acceptor" approach. Based on empirical evidence, we provide some schematic representations to describe the possible mechanisms governing the evolution of the two-band spectral absorption obsd. on varying the relative compn. of electron-rich and electron-deficient substituents along the π-conjugated backbone. In parallel, we draw attention to the choice of the method employed to est. and compare the absorption coeffs. of polymer chromophores exhibiting distinct repeat unit lengths, and contg. various extents of solubilizing side-chains along their backbone. Finally, we discuss the common assumption that "donor-acceptor" systems should have systematically lower absorption coeffs. than their "all-donor" counterparts. The proposed models point toward important theor. parameters which could be further explored at the macromol. level to help researchers take full advantage of the complex interactions taking place in π-conjugated polymers with intramol. "donor-acceptor" characteristics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVGrsLvK&md5=0bbbe078124296890ffce78d02e85c3d
        (c) Li, Y. F. Molecular design of photovoltaic materials for polymer solar cells: toward suitable electronic energy levels and broad absorption Acc. Chem. Res. 2012, 45, 723– 733 DOI: 10.1021/ar2002446
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16c
        Molecular Design of Photovoltaic Materials for Polymer Solar Cells: Electronic Energy Levels and Broad Absorption
        Li, Yongfang
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2012), 45 (5), 723-733CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Bulk heterojunction (BHJ) polymer solar cells (PSCs) sandwich a blend layer of conjugated polymer donor and fullerene deriv. acceptor between a transparent ITO pos. electrode and a low work function metal neg. electrode. In comparison with traditional inorg. semiconductor solar cells, PSCs offer a simpler device structure, easier fabrication, lower cost, and lighter wt., and these structures can be fabricated into flexible devices. But currently the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the PSCs is not sufficient for future commercialization. The polymer donors and fullerene deriv. acceptors are the key photovoltaic materials that will need to be optimized for high-performance PSCs. The basic requirements and scientific issues are discussed in the mol. design of high efficiency photovoltaic mols. Recent progress is also summarized in electronic energy level engineering and absorption spectral broadening of the donor and acceptor photovoltaic materials by my research group and others. For high-efficiency conjugated polymer donors, key requirements are a narrower energy bandgap (Eg) and broad absorption, relatively lower-lying HOMO level, and higher hole mobility. There are three strategies to meet these requirements: D-A copolymn. for narrower Eg and lower-lying HOMO, substitution with electron-withdrawing groups for lower-lying HOMO, and two-dimensional conjugation for broad absorption and higher hole mobility. Moreover, better main chain planarity and less side chain steric hindrance could strengthen π-π stacking and increase hole mobility. Furthermore, the mol. wt. of the polymers also influences their photovoltaic performance. To produce high efficiency photovoltaic polymers, researchers should attempt to increase mol. wt. while maintaining soly. High-efficiency D-A copolymers were obtained by using benzodithiophene (BDT), dithienosilole (DTS), or indacenodithiophene (IDT) donor unit and benzothiadiazole (BT), thienopyrrole-dione (TPD), or thiazolothiazole (TTz) acceptor units. The BDT unit with two thienyl conjugated side chains is a highly promising unit in constructing high-efficiency copolymer donor materials. The electron-withdrawing groups of ester, ketone, fluorine, or sulfonyl can effectively tune the HOMO energy levels downward. To improve the performance of fullerene deriv. acceptors, researchers will need to strengthen absorption in the visible spectrum, upshift the LUMO energy level, and increase the electron mobility. [6,6]-Phenyl-C71-butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) is superior to [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) because C70 absorbs visible light more efficiently. Indene-C60 bisadduct (ICBA) and Indene-C70 bisadduct (IC70BA) show 0.17 and 0.19 eV higher LUMO energy levels, resp., than PCBM, due to the electron-rich character of indene and the effect of bisadduct. ICBA and IC70BA are excellent acceptors for the P3HT-based PSCs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsVyrtr0%253D&md5=0c17f7095d4bc40d80db35233f0dc35f
        (d) Neto, B. A. D.; Lapis, A. A. M.; da Silva Júnior, E. N.; Dupont, J. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole and derivatives: synthesis, properties, reactions, and applications in light technology of small molecules Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2013, 2013, 228– 255 DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201201161
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
