        2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole and Derivatives: Synthesis, Properties, Reactions, and Applications in Light Technology of Small Molecules
        Neto, Brenno A. D.; Lapis, Alexandre A. M.; da Silva, Eufranio N., Jr.; Dupont, Jairton
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 2013 (2), 228-255CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole (BTD) is one of the most important nuclei used in the chem. of photoluminescent compds. and applicable for light technol. The understanding of its properties and reactions is fundamental for the design and application of these derivs. in mol. org. electronic devices and for other technologies. As a result of their potential as constituents of org. light-emitting diodes, solar cells, liq. crystals, dyes, photovoltaic cells, and many others, attention has been focused on BTD π-extended derivs. with potential use in this exciting area. Herein, we describe their syntheses, properties, reactions, and selected examples of applications in light technol. using by BTD (small mols.) as the core.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVSisb3E&md5=0cacae09ae86eff8844d5958eea3726a
        (e) Parker, T. C.; Pa-tel, D. G.; Moudgil, K.; Barlow, S.; Risko, C.; Brédas, J. L.; Reynolds, J. R.; Marder, S. R. Heteroannulated acceptors based on benzothiadiazole Mater. Horiz. 2015, 2, 22– 36 DOI: 10.1039/C4MH00102H
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16e
        Heteroannulated acceptors based on benzothiadiazole
        Parker, Timothy C.; Patel, Dinesh G.; Moudgil, Karttikay; Barlow, Stephen; Risko, Chad; Bredas, Jean-Luc; Reynolds, John R.; Marder, Seth R.
        Materials Horizons (2015), 2 (1), 22-36CODEN: MHAOBM; ISSN:2051-6355. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Increasing the acceptor strength of the widely used acceptor benzothiadiazole (BT) by extending the heterocyclic core is a promising strategy for developing new and stronger acceptors for materials in org. electronics and photonics. In recent years, such heteroannulated BT acceptors have been incorporated into a wide variety of materials that have been used in org. electronic and photonic devices. This review critically assesses the properties of these materials. Although heteroannulation to form acceptors, such as benzo[1,2-c:4,5-c']bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole (BBT), does result in materials with significantly higher electron affinity (EA) relative to BT, in many cases the extended BT systems also exhibit lower ionization energy (IE) than BT. Both the significantly higher EA and lower IE limit the efficacy of these materials in applications such as bulk heterojunction org. photovoltaics (BHJ-OPV) based on C60. Although the relatively high EA may enable some applications such as air stable org. field effect transistors (OFET), more widespread use of heteroannulated BT acceptors will likely require the ability to moderate or retain the high EA while increasing IE.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1yltbzK&md5=843e9582cce834180e6ae22f18ad28d9
        (f) Neto, B. A. D.; Carvalho, P. H. P. R.; Correa, J. R. Acc. Chem. Res. 2015, 48, 1560– 1569 DOI: 10.1021/ar500468p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16f
        Benzothiadiazole Derivatives as Fluorescence Imaging Probes: Beyond Classical Scaffolds
        Neto, Brenno A. D.; Carvalho, Pedro H. P. R.; Correa, Jose R.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2015), 48 (6), 1560-1569CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. This Account describes the origins, features, importance, and trends of the use of fluorescent small-mol. 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (BTD) derivs. as a new class of bioprobes applied to bioimaging analyses of several (live and fixed) cell types. BTDs have been successfully used as probes for a plethora of biol. analyses for only a few years, and the impressive responses obtained by using this important class of heterocycle are fostering the development of new fluorescent BTDs and expanding the biol. applications of such derivs. The first use of a fluorescent small-mol. BTD deriv. as a selective cellular probe dates back to 2010, and since then impressive advances have been described by the authors and others. The known limitations of classical scaffolds urged the development of new classes of bioprobes. Although great developments have been achieved by using classical scaffolds such as coumarins, BODIPYs, fluoresceins, rhodamines, cyanines, and phenoxazines, there is still much to be done, and BTDs aim to succeed where these dyes showed their limitations. Important organelles and cell components such as nuclear DNA, mitochondria, lipid droplets, and others have already been successfully labeled by fluorescent small-mol. BTD derivs. New technol. systems that use BTDs as the fluorophores for bioimaging expts. have been described in recent scientific literature. The successful application of BTDs as selective bioprobes led some groups to explore their potential for use in studying membrane pores or tumor cells under hypoxic conditions. Finally, BTDs have also been used as fluorescent tags to study the action mechanism of some antitumor compds. The attractive photophys. data typically obsd. for π-extended BTD derivs. is fostering interest in the use of this new class of bioprobes. Large Stokes shifts, large molar absorptivities, high quantum yields, high stability when stored in soln. or as pure solids, no fading even after long periods of irradn., bright emissions with no blinking, good signal-to-noise ratios, efficiency to transpose the cell membrane, and irradn. preferentially in the visible-light region are just some features noted by using BTDs. As the pioneering group in the use of fluorescent small-mol. BTDs for bioimaging purposes, the authors feel pleased to share the authors' experience, results, advances, and personal perspectives with the readers of this Account. The readers will clearly note the huge advantages of using fluorescent BTDs over classical scaffolds, and hopefully they will be inspired and motivated to further BTD technol. in the fields of mol. and cellular biol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosFGrtrY%253D&md5=ccac736fa242dc4c07184236cc335874
      17. 17
        (a) Espinet, P.; Echavarren, A. M. The mechanisms of the stille reaction Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 4704– 4734 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200300638
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17a
        C-C coupling: The mechanisms of the Stille reaction
        Espinet, Pablo; Echavarren, Antonio M.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (36), 4704-4734CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Eighteen years ago in Angewandte Chemie John K. Stille reviewed a novel methodol., which eventually became known by his name, for the coupling of organostannanes with org. electrophiles. The mechanism of the consecutive steps of the reaction, oxidative addn. of org. electrophile to Pd(0) complex, transmetalation, reductive elimination of biaryls are reviewed. Role of side reactions, such as scrambling of substituents and homocoupling is also considered. Effects of bidentate ligands, anions and palladium precursors is illustrated with several examples. Mechanism of transmetalation, including isolation of stable diorganopalladium species, enhancement of stannane reactivity by fluoride and hydroxide anions, is described in details. Very recent modifications are making synthetic wishes come true that were only dreamed of a few years ago. So-called "copper effect" ascribes the acceleration of the coupling reaction either to free phosphine scavenging by added CuI, or Sn-Cu transmetalation prior to formation of diorganopalladium intermediate. Use of N-heterocyclic carbenes as ligands allows substantial improvement in chemoselectivity and activity of palladium catalysts, suppressing undesired homocoupling and accelerating the reductive elimination step. In some cases, the Stille coupling proceeds via oxidative addn. of alkynylstannanes with Pd(0) complexes, with subsequent substitution of Pd-bound organotin group by aryl ligand. Moreover, as important advances are being made in the understanding of the mechanistic details of the process, it is becoming increasingly possible to apply this essential reaction and its new variants in a less empirical way.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXotVGis7g%253D&md5=32481a2c7e9cb4003f3586e484c71e55
        (b) Suzuki, A. Carbon-carbon bonding made easy Chem. Commun. 2005, 38, 4759– 4763 DOI: 10.1039/b507375h
        [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (c) Sonar, P.; Singh, S. P.; Sudhakar, S.; Dodabalapur, A.; Sellinger, A. High-mobility organic thin film transistors based on benzothiadiazole-sandwiched dihexylquaterthiophenes Chem. Mater. 2008, 20, 3184– 3190 DOI: 10.1021/cm800139q
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17c
        High-Mobility Organic Thin Film Transistors Based on Benzothiadiazole-Sandwiched Dihexylquaterthiophenes
        Sonar, Prashant; Singh, Samarendra P.; Sudhakar, Sundarraj; Dodabalapur, Ananth; Sellinger, Alan
        Chemistry of Materials (2008), 20 (9), 3184-3190CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors report here the synthesis, characterization, and org. thin-film transistor (OTFT) mobilities of 4,7-bis(5-(5-hexylthiophen-2-yl)thiophen-2-yl)benzo[1,2,5]thiadiazole (DH-BTZ-4T). DH-BTZ-4T was prepd. in one high-yield step from com. available materials using Suzuki chem. and purified by column chromatog. OTFTs with hole mobilities of 0.17 cm2/(Vs) and on/off current ratios of 1 × 105 were prepd. from DH-BTZ-4T active layers deposited by vacuum deposition. As DH-BTZ-4T is sol. in common solvents, soln. processed devices were also prepd. by spin coating yielding preliminary mobilities of 6.0 × 10-3 cm2/(Vs). The promising mobilities and low band gap (1.90 eV) coupled with soln. processability and ambient stability makes this material an excellent candidate for application in org. electronics.

        (d) Zhu, W. H.; Meng, X. L.; Yang, Y. H.; Zhang, Q.; Xie, Y. S.; Tian, H. Bisthienylethenes containing a benzothiadiazole unit as a bridge: photochromic performance dependence on substitution position Chem. - Eur. J. 2010, 16, 899– 906 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200901855
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17d
        Bisthienylethenes Containing a Benzothiadiazole Unit as a Bridge: Photochromic Performance Dependence on Substitution Position
        Zhu, Weihong; Meng, Xianle; Yang, Yuheng; Zhang, Qiong; Xie, Yongshu; Tian, He
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (3), 899-906, S899/1-S899/23CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A conveniently synthesized photochromic compd., BTB-1 (I), contg. an unprecedented six-membered 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole unit as the center ethene bridge, possesses good photochromic performance, with a high cyclization quantum yield and moderate fatigue resistance in soln. or an organogel system. The fluorescence of I can be modulated by solvato- and photochromism. However, the analog BTB-2 (II), in which the dimethylthiophene substituents are relocated to the 5,6-positions of benzothiadiazole, does not show any detectable photochromism. To the best of knowledge, this is the first example of six-membered bridge bisthienylethenes (BTEs) in which the photochromism can be controlled by the substitution position. The photochromism difference is elucidated by the anal. of resonance structure, the Woodward-Hoffmann rule, and theor. calcns. on the ground-state potential-energy surface. In a well-ordered single-crystal state, I adopts a relatively rare parallel conformation, and forms an interesting two-dimensional structure due to the presence of multiple directional intermol. interactions, including C-H···N and C-H···S hydrogen-bonding interactions, and π-π stacking interactions. This work contributes to several aspects for developing novel photochromic BTE systems with fluorescence modulation and performances controlled by substitution position in different states (soln., organogel, and single crystal).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXos1Ggtg%253D%253D&md5=4f88dabe643c3caff181a7b3fbf63ccc
        (e) Shen, M.; Rodríguez-López, J.; Huang, J.; Liu, Q.; Zhu, X. H.; Bard, A. J. Electrochemistry and electrogenerated chemiluminescence of dithienylbenzothiadiazole derivative. differential reactivity of donor and acceptor groups and simulations of radical cation-anion and dcation-radical anion annihilations J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 13453– 13461 DOI: 10.1021/ja105282u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17e
        Electrochemistry and Electrogenerated Chemiluminescence of Dithienylbenzothiadiazole Derivative. Differential Reactivity of Donor and Acceptor Groups and Simulations of Radical Cation-Anion and Dication-Radical Anion Annihilations
        Shen, Mei; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin; Huang, Ju; Liu, Quan; Zhu, Xu-Hui; Bard, Allen J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (38), 13453-13461CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        We report here the electrochem. and electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) of a red-emitting dithienylbenzothiadiazole-based mol. fluorophore (4,7-bis(4-(4-sec-butoxyphenyl)-5-(3,5-di(1-naphthyl)phenyl)thiophen-2-yl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole, 1b). 1b contains two substituted thiophene groups as strong electron donors at the ends connected directly to a strong electron acceptor, 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole, in the center. Each thiophene moiety is substituted in position 2 by 3,5-di(1-naphthyl)phenyl and in position 3 by 4-sec-butoxyphenyl. Cyclic voltammetry of 1b, with scan rate ranging from 0.05 to 0.75 V/s, shows a single one-electron redn. wave (E°red = -1.18 V vs SCE) and two nernstian one-electron oxidn. waves (E°1,ox = 1.01 V, E°2,ox = 1.24 V vs SCE). Redn. of the unsubstituted 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole center shows nernstian behavior with E°red = -1.56 V vs SCE. By comparison to a digital simulation, the heterogeneous electron-transfer rate const. for redn., kr° = 1.5 × 10-3 cm/s, is significantly smaller than those for the oxidns., ko° > 0.1 cm/s, possibly indicating that the two substituted end groups have a blocking effect on the redn. of the benzothiadiazole center. The ECL spectrum, produced by electron-transfer annihilation of the reduced and oxidized forms, consists of a single peak with max. emission at about 635 nm, consistent with the fluorescence of the parent mol. Relative ECL intensities with respect to 9,10-diphenylanthracene are 330% and 470% for the radical anion-cation and radical anion-dication annihilation, resp. Radical anion (A-·)-cation (A+·) annihilation produced by potential steps shows sym. ECL transients during anodic and cathodic pulses, while for anion (A-·)-dication (A2+·) annihilation, transient ECL shows asymmetry in which the anodic pulse is narrower than the cathodic pulse. Digital simulation of the transient ECL expts. showed that the origin of the obsd. asymmetry is asymmetry in the amt. of generated charges rather than instability of the electrogenerated species.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFWlsbzI&md5=d5507daecceb581dff3c1f166648ce10

        (a) Lin, R. Y. Y.; Lee, C. P.; Chen, Y. C.; Peng, J. D.; Chu, T. C.; Chou, H. H.; Yang, H. M.; Lin, J. T.; Ho, K. C. Benzothiadiazole-containing donor-acceptor-acceptor type organic sensitizers for solar cells with ZnO photoanodes Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 12071– 12073 DOI: 10.1039/c2cc37184g
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18a
        Benzothiadiazole-containing donor-acceptor-acceptor type organic sensitizers for solar cells with ZnO photoanodes
        Lin, Ryan Yeh-Yung; Lee, Chuan-Pei; Chen, Yung-Chung; Peng, Jia-De; Chu, Te-Chun; Chou, Hsien-Hsin; Yang, Hung-Ming; Lin, Jiann T.; Ho, Kuo-Chuan
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (99), 12071-12073CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Dye-sensitized solar cells using nanocryst. ZnO as the photoanode and a metal-free sensitizer with a benzothiadiazole entity directly connected to the 2-cyanoacrylic acid acceptor exhibited an efficiency (5.18%) higher than those using the TiO2 photoanode. Use of a hierarchical ZnO back scattering layer further improved the efficiency to 5.82%.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhs12rs7vO&md5=d4bfde0add58a1e1a42a319d7c6f0a94
        (b) Sonar, P.; Williams, E. L.; Singh, S. P.; Manzhos, S.; Dodabalapur, A. A benzothiadiazole end capped donor-acceptor based small molecule for organic electronics Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2013, 15, 17064– 17069 DOI: 10.1039/c3cp52929k
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18b
        A benzothiadiazole end capped donor-acceptor based small molecule for organic electronics
        Sonar, Prashant; Williams, Evan L.; Singh, Samarendra P.; Manzhos, Sergei; Dodabalapur, Ananth
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2013), 15 (40), 17064-17069CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A benzothiadiazole end-capped small mol. 3,6-bis(5-(benzo[c][1,2,5]thiadiazol-4-yl)thiophen-2-yl)-2,5-bis(2-butyloctyl)pyrrolo[3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4(2H,5H)-dione (BO-DPP-BTZ) using a fused arom. moiety DPP (at the center) is designed and synthesized. BO-DPP-BTZ is a donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) structure which possesses a band gap of 1.6 eV and exhibits a strong solid state ordering inferred from ∼120 nm red shift of the absorption maxima from soln. to thin film. Field-effect transistors using a spin coated thin film of BO-DPP-BTZ as an active layer exhibited a hole mobility of 0.06 cm2 V-1 s-1. Soln.-processed bulk heterojunction org. photovoltaics employing a blend of BO-DPP-BTZ and [70]PCBM demonstrated a power conversion efficiency of 0.9%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1Wnsb3K&md5=c0e3d8425b7403937209648b712a7d5c
        (c) Pop, F.; Amacher, A.; Avarvari, N.; Ding, J.; Daku, L. M. L.; Hauser, A.; Koch, M.; Hauser, J.; Liu, S. X.; Decurtins, S. Tetrathiafulvalene-benzothiadiazoles as redox-tunable donor-acceptor systems: synthesis and photophysical study Chem. - Eur. J. 2013, 19, 2504– 2514 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201202742

        18c
        Tetrathiafulvalene-Benzothiadiazoles as Redox-Tunable Donor-Acceptor Systems: Synthesis and Photophysical Study
        Pop, Flavia; Amacher, Anneliese; Avarvari, Narcis; Ding, Jie; Daku, Latevi Max Lawson; Hauser, Andreas; Koch, Marius; Hauser, Juerg; Liu, Shi-Xia; Decurtins, Silvio
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (7), 2504-2514CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Electrochem. and photophys. anal. of new donor-acceptor systems 2 and 3, in which a benzothiadiazole (BTD) unit is covalently linked to a tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) core, have verified that the lowest excited state can be ascribed to an intramol.-charge-transfer (ICT) π(TTF)→π*(BTD) transition. Owing to better overlap of the HOMO and LUMO in the fused scaffold of compd. 3, the intensity of the ICT band is substantially higher compared to that in compd. 2. The corresponding CT fluorescence is also obsd. in both cases. The radical cation TTF+. is easily obsd. through chem. and electrochem. oxidn. by performing steady-state absorption expts. Interestingly, compd. 2 is photo-oxidized under aerobic conditions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXkvFGnsw%253D%253D&md5=a398d318229737fda886578b242ec4a2
      19. 19
        (a) Yang, G.; Di, C. A.; Zhang, G. X.; Zhang, J.; Xiang, J. F.; Zhang, D. Q.; Zhu, D. Highly sensitive chemical-vapor sensor based on thin-film organic field-effect transistors with benzothiadiazole-fused-tetrathiafulvalene Adv. Funct. Mater. 2013, 23, 1671– 1676 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201202473
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19a
        Highly sensitive chemical-vapor sensor based on thin-film organic field-effect transistors with benzothiadiazole-fused-tetrathiafulvalene
        Yang, Ge; Di, Chong-an; Zhang, Guanxin; Zhang, Jing; Xiang, Junfeng; Zhang, Deqing; Zhu, Daoben
        Advanced Functional Materials (2013), 23 (13), 1671-1676CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The synthesis of a new tetrathiafulvalene deriv. with an electron-withdrawing benzothiadiazole moiety and its use in thin-film org. field-effect transistors (OFETs) are reported. Compared to reported OFETs with other TTF derivs., a high hole mobility up to 0.73 cm2 V-1 s-1, low off-current and high on/off ratio up to 105 are demonstrated. In addn., the developed OFETs show fast responsiveness toward chem. vapors of DECP (di-Et chlorophosphate) or POCl3 which are simulants of phosphate-based nerve agents. In contrast to previously reported OFET-based sensors, off-current is used as the output signal, which increases quickly upon exposure to either DECP or POCl3 vapors. High sensitivity is demonstrated toward DECP and POCl3 vapors, with concns. as low as 10 ppb being detected. These OFETs are also responsive to TNT vapor. The sensing mechanisms for the new type of OFET are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsFyjsb%252FP&md5=006fb7a3275342986ac13674686ecf84
        (b) Tucker, N. M.; Briseno, A. L.; Acton, O.; Yip, H. L.; Ma, H.; Jenekhe, S. A.; Xia, Y. N.; Jen, A. K. Y. Solvent-dispersed benzothiadiazole-tetrathiafulvalene single-crystal nanowires and their application in field-effect transistors ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2013, 5, 2320– 2324 DOI: 10.1021/am3025036
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19b
        Solvent-Dispersed Benzothiadiazole-Tetrathiafulvalene Single-Crystal Nanowires and Their Application in Field-Effect Transistors
        Tucker, Neil M.; Briseno, Alejandro L.; Acton, Orb; Yip, Hin-Lap; Ma, Hong; Jenekhe, Samson A.; Xia, Younan; Jen, Alex K.-Y.
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2013), 5 (7), 2320-2324CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        A new org. semiconductor (BT-TTF) based on mol. moieties of benzothiadiazole and tetrathiafulvalene was designed and synthesized, and its structure, mol. packing and charge-transporting properties were detd. Thermal properties, electrochem. behaviors, and optical absorption of this mol. were studied by using DSC/TGA, cyclic voltammetry, and UV-visible spectroscopy, resp. Its bulk and nanowire single crystals were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog., SEM, TEM, and field-effect transistors. Short intermol. S···S (3.41 Å), S···C (3.49 Å), and S···N (3.05 Å) contacts define the solid-state structure of BT-TTF single crystals which π-stack along the [100] with interplanar distances of 3.49 Å. Solvent-cast single-crystal nanowire transistors showed mobilities as large as 0.36 cm2/(V s) with current on/off ratios of 1 × 106. This study further illustrates the impact of mol. design and a demonstration of high-performance single-crystal nanowire transistors from the resulting semiconductor.

        (c) Gautam, P.; Misra, R.; Siddiqui, S. A.; Sharma, G. D. Unsymmetrical donor-acceptor-acceptor-π-donor type benzothiadiazole-based small molecule for a solution processed bulk heterojunction organic solar cell ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2015, 7, 10283– 10292 DOI: 10.1021/acsami.5b02250
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19c
        Unsymmetrical Donor-Acceptor-Acceptor-π-Donor Type Benzothiadiazole-Based Small Molecule for a Solution Processed Bulk Heterojunction Organic Solar Cell
        Gautam, Prabhat; Misra, Rajneesh; Siddiqui, Shahbaz A.; Sharma, Ganesh D.
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2015), 7 (19), 10283-10292CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        A D1-A-A'-π-D2 type (D = donor; A = acceptor) unsym. small mol. denoted as BTD3 contg. different end group donor moieties has been designed and synthesized for use as a donor in the soln. processable bulk heterojunction (BHJ) solar cell. The BTD3 exhibits a low HOMO-LUMO gap of 1.68 eV and deeper HOMO energy level (-5.5 eV). Its LUMO energy level (-3.65 eV) is compatible with the LUMO level of PC71BM to facilitate the electron transfer from BTD3 to PC71BM in the BHJ solar cell. The soln. processed BHJ solar cell with optimized BTD3:PC71BM active layer processed with THF solvent exhibited a PCE of 3.15% with Jsc = 7.45 mA/cm2, Voc = 0.94 V, and FF = 0.45. Moreover, the device with optimized concn. of 3 vol. % 1-chloronaphthalene (CN) additive, i.e., CN/THF, showed significant enhancement in PCE up to 4.61% (Jsc = 9.48 mA/cm2, Voc = 0.90 V, and FF = 0.54). The improvement in the PCE has been attributed to the appropriate nanoscale phase sepn. morphol., balance charge transport, and enhancement in the light harvesting ability of the active layer.

        (a) van Vooren, A.; Kim, J.-S., Prof.; Cornil, J., Dr. Intrachain versus interchain electron transport in poly(fluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole): a quantum-chemical insight ChemPhysChem 2008, 9, 989– 993 DOI: 10.1002/cphc.200700847
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20a
        Intrachain versus interchain electron transport in poly(fluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole): a quantum-chemical insight
        Van Vooren, Antoine; Kim, Ji-Seon; Cornil, Jerome
        ChemPhysChem (2008), 9 (7), 989-993CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Poly(9,9-di-n-octylfluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole) [F8BT], displays very different charge-transport properties for holes vs. electrons when comparing annealed and pristine thin films and transport parallel (intrachain) and perpendicular (interchain) to the polymer axes. The present theor. contribution focuses on the electron-transport properties of F8BT chains and compares the efficiency of intrachain vs. interchain transport in the hopping regime. The theor. results rationalize significantly lowered electron mobility in annealed F8BT thin films and the smaller mobility anisotropy (μ‖/μ.perp.) measured for electrons in aligned films (i.e. 5-7 compared to 10-15 for holes).

        2,1,3-benzothiadiazole dimers: preparation, structure, and transannular electronic interactions of syn- and anti-[2.2](4,7)benzothiadiazolophanes
        Watanabe, Motonori; Goto, Kenta; Fujitsuka, Mamoru; Tojo, Sachiko; Majima, Tetsuro; Shinmyozu, Teruo

        The cyclophanes comprised of two 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (BTD) rings, anti- and syn-[2.2](4,7)benzothiadiazolophanes (anti-1 and syn-1), were prepd. for the first time. The differences of the phys. properties in the overlapping mode of the π-systems are clearly obsd., and syn-1 shows much more significant transannular π-electronic interactions than anti-1 esp. in the redox properties and the stability of the radical anion species.

        A new NbO-type metal-org. framework ZJNU-40 incorporating highly polarized benzothiadiazole moieties exhibits a high CO2 uptake of 108 cm3 g-1 at 296 K and 1 atm, as well as good adsorption selectivities of CO2 over CH4 and N2 at room temp., which is superior to that of the analogous MOF NOTT-101.

        Agneeswari, R.; Tamilavan, V.; Song, M.; Hyun, M. H.         Property modulation of benzodithiophene-based polymers via the incorporation of a covalently bonded novel 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole-1,2,4-oxadiazole derivative in their main chain for polymer solar cells
        Agneeswari, Rajalingam; Tamilavan, Vellaiappillai; Song, Myungkwan; Hyun, Myung Ho
        Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices (2014), 2 (40), 8515-8524CODEN: JMCCCX; ISSN:2050-7534. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two new electron accepting monomers (BBOB and BOB) contg. two serially connected different electron deficient units, such as 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole and 1,2,4-oxadiazole, were prepd. and copolymd. with electron-rich benzodithiophene (BDT) deriv. to afford polymers P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB), resp. The optical band gaps of P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB) are calcd. to be 2.32 eV and 1.99 eV, resp., and their highest occupied mol. energy levels are detd. to be -5.31 eV and -5.27 eV, resp. Each of the newly synthesized polymers, i.e.P(BDT-BBOB) and P(BDT-BOB), is used as an electron donor, along with PC61BM as an electron acceptor, in the prepn. of polymer solar cells (PSCs). The PSCs made with the configuration of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/P(BDT-BBOB) or P(BDT-BOB):PC61BM (1 : 2 wt%)/LiF/Al gave a max. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 1.76% and 2.46%, resp., and the device performance was further improved to 3.31% and 4.21%, resp., by simply treating the photoactive layer of PSCs with iso-Pr alc. Overall, the opto-elec. and photovoltaic properties of the two polymers are quite dependent on the configuration of the covalently bonded 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole and 1,2,4-oxadiazole units incorporated in the polymer main chain.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVSmtLnO&md5=c7fa62593f7f8c18ffff8ec29c2811ba
      23. 23
        Sheldrick, G. M. A short history of SHELX Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Found. Crystallogr. 2008, A64, 112– 122 DOI: 10.1107/S0108767307043930
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e

        Orpen, A. G.; Brammer, L.; Allen, F. H.; Kennard, O.; Watson, D. G.; Taylor, R. Tables of bond lengths determined by X-Ray and neutron diffraction. Part 2. Organometallic compounds and Co-ordination complexes of the d- and f-block metals J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans. 1989, S1– S83 DOI: 10.1039/dt98900000s1
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Tables of bond lengths determined by x-ray and neutron diffraction. Part 2. Organometallic compounds and coordination complexes of the d- and f-block metals
        Orpen, A. Guy; Brammer, Lee; Allen, Frank H.; Kennard, Olga; Watson, David G.; Taylor, Robin
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1972-1999) (1989), (12), S1-S83CODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246.
        Av. lengths for metal-ligand bonds are reported, together with some intraligand distances, for complexes of the d- and f-block metals. Mean values are presented for 325 different bond types involving metal atoms bonded to H, B, C, N, O, F, Si, P, S, Cl, As, Se, Br, Te, or I atoms of the ligands.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXivVCmsw%253D%253D&md5=8829b3e5ab4355e84cd7dec1b00d436a
      25. 25
        DaSilveira Neto, B. A.; Lopes, A. S. A.; Ebeling, G.; Gonçalves, R. S.; Costa, V. E. U.; Quina, F. H.; Dupont, J. Photophysical and electrochemical properties of π-extended molecular 2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles Tetrahedron 2005, 61, 10975– 10982 DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2005.08.093
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Photophysical and electrochemical properties of π-extended molecular 2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles
        Da Silveira Neto, Brenno A.; Sant'Ana Lopes, Aline; Ebeling, Gunter; Goncalves, Reinaldo S.; Costa, Valentim E. U.; Quina, Frank H.; Dupont, Jairton
        Tetrahedron (2005), 61 (46), 10975-10982CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The reaction of 4,7-dibromo-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole with arylboronic acids [aryl = Ph, 1-naphthyl, 4-methoxyphenyl, 4-chlorophenyl, and 4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl] in the presence of catalytic amts. of an NCP-pincer palladacycle affords photoluminescent π-extended 4,7-diaryl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles in high yields. These 4,7-diaryl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles exhibit high fluorescent quantum yields, high electron affinities, and adequate band gap values for testing as OLEDs. 4,7-Bis(1-naphthyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole presents two different lifetimes (bi-exponential decay) due to the presence of two atropisomers. The Sonogashira coupling reaction of 4,7-diethynyl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole with the corresponding haloaryl compds. (iodobenzene, 1-bromonaphthalene, 4-iodoanisole, 4-bromo-N,N-dimethylaniline, and 2-bromopyridine) afforded the photoluminescent π-extended 4,7-bis(arylethynyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles, also in high yields. These 4,7-bis(arylethynyl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles also present high fluorescent quantum yields, high electron affinities, and adequate band gap values for testing as OLEDs. The 4,7-disubstituted-2,1,3-benzothiadiazoles exhibit different electrochem. behavior. The presence of the two ethynyl spacers in the benzothiadiazoles shifts the redn. potentials to less cathodic values and also results in two well-defined and distinct redn. processes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFCntr7E&md5=c8fa345968fc8fe2ebc7bebd8b9e3939
